title: The Tempest
author: William Shakespeare
description: magic, shipwreck, and revenge on a remote island
introAnnotation: Written around 1610‚Äì11, The Tempest is believed to be the last play Shakespeare wrote on his own. It was partly inspired by real accounts of the Sea Venture, an English ship wrecked on Bermuda in 1609 while sailing to the Virginia colony. The play explores power, forgiveness, colonialism, and the nature of art itself ‚Äî themes that feel remarkably current four centuries later. Unusually for Shakespeare, the plot appears to be entirely original rather than adapted from an existing source.
dramatis: Prospero ‚Äî the rightful Duke of Milan, exiled to a remote island
Miranda ‚Äî his daughter, raised on the island
Ariel ‚Äî a spirit bound to serve Prospero
Caliban ‚Äî a native of the island, enslaved by Prospero
Antonio ‚Äî Prospero's brother, usurper of his dukedom
Adrian & Francisco ‚Äî lords attending the King
Boatswain ‚Äî officer in charge of the deck crew
Iris, Ceres, Juno ‚Äî spirits appearing in a masque

lines.text: Act I, Scene 1 ‚Äî A ship at sea. A tempestuous noise of thunder and lightning heard.
lines.annotation: The play opens in medias res ‚Äî in the middle of the action.

lines.text: Boatswain!
lines.annotation: Boatswain (pronounced 'BOH-sun'), the officer in charge of the deck crew and rigging.

lines.text: Here, master. What cheer?
lines.annotation: 'What cheer?' means 'What's the situation?' or 'What are your orders?' ‚Äî a common sailor's greeting.

lines.text: Good, speak to the mariners. Fall to't yarely, or we run ourselves aground. Bestir, bestir!
lines.annotation: 'Yarely' means quickly, nimbly. 'Bestir' means hurry, get moving.

lines.text: Enter Mariners.
Heigh, my hearts! Cheerly, cheerly, my hearts! Yare, yare! Take in the topsail. Tend to the master's whistle.
lines.annotation: 'Heigh, my hearts!' ‚Äî a rallying cry, like 'Come on, lads!' 'Cheerly' means with spirit. 'Take in the topsail' ‚Äî lower the sail near the top of the mast. The master's whistle signals commands.

lines.text: Blow, till thou burst thy wind, if room enough!
lines.annotation: He's addressing the storm directly: 'Blow as hard as you want ‚Äî as long as we have sea room to maneuver.'

lines.text: Enter Alonso, Sebastian, Antonio, Ferdinand, Gonzalo, and others.
lines.annotation: The nobles stumble onto deck. Alonso is King of Naples. Sebastian is his brother. Antonio is Prospero's brother who usurped his dukedom. Ferdinand is the King's son. Gonzalo is an honest old counselor.

lines.text: Good Boatswain, have care. Where's the master? Play the men.
lines.annotation: The King tries to take charge. 'Play the men' means 'put the men to work.' But he's giving orders on a ship he doesn't command.

lines.text: I pray now, keep below.
lines.annotation: 'Please, stay below deck.' The Boatswain is too busy trying to save the ship to observe courtly manners.

lines.text: Where is the master, Boatswain?
Do you not hear him? You mar our labour. Keep your cabins; you do assist the storm.
lines.annotation: 'You mar our labour' ‚Äî you're getting in our way. 'You assist the storm' ‚Äî you're making things worse by being here.

lines.text: Nay, good, be patient.
lines.annotation: Gonzalo, the kind old counselor, urging patience ‚Äî addressing his fellow nobles, not the crew.

lines.text: When the sea is. Hence! What cares these roarers for the name of king? To cabin! Silence; trouble us not.
lines.annotation: 'Hence!' means go away. 'Roarers' ‚Äî the roaring waves and wind. His point: the sea doesn't care about social rank.

lines.text: Good, yet remember whom thou hast aboard.
lines.annotation: A reminder that the Boatswain is speaking to a king.

lines.text: None that I more love than myself. You are a councillor; if you can command these elements to silence and work the peace of the present, we will not hand a rope more. Use your authority.
lines.annotation: 'If your political authority can calm the storm, go ahead ‚Äî we'll stop working and watch.' He's testing the limits of earthly power against nature.

lines.text: If you cannot, give thanks you have lived so long, and make yourself ready in your cabin for the mischance of the hour, if it so hap. Cheerly, good hearts! Out of our way, I say.
lines.annotation: 'Make yourself ready for the mischance of the hour' ‚Äî prepare to die.

lines.text: Exit.
I have great comfort from this fellow. Methinks he hath no drowning mark upon him; his complexion is perfect gallows.
lines.annotation: Dark humor: Gonzalo finds comfort because the Boatswain looks destined for the gallows, not drowning. An old superstition held that a man born to hang can't drown. 'Perfect gallows' means his face is destined for the noose.

lines.text: Stand fast, good Fate, to his hanging. Make the rope of his destiny our cable, for our own doth little advantage. If he be not born to be hanged, our case is miserable.
lines.annotation: Gonzalo continues his gallows joke: let Fate make sure this man hangs ‚Äî because that would mean we survive this storm. 'Our cable' (anchor rope) isn't helping; maybe his destiny to hang will save us. If he's NOT destined to hang, we're doomed.

lines.text: Re-enter Boatswain.
lines.annotation: The Boatswain returns as the storm reaches its peak. The nobles, instead of going below as ordered, have followed him back on deck.

lines.text: A pox o' your throat, you bawling, blasphemous, incharitable dog!
lines.annotation: 'Incharitable' ‚Äî lacking Christian charity. Sebastian loses his composure as the panic sets in.

lines.text: Work you, then.
lines.annotation: If you have a problem with how I'm doing it, do it yourself.

lines.text: Hang, cur! Hang, you whoreson, insolent noise-maker. We are less afraid to be drowned than thou art.
lines.annotation: 'Cur' ‚Äî dog. 'Whoreson' ‚Äî bastard. His claim that the nobles fear death less than the Boatswain is hollow bravado.

lines.text: I'll warrant him for drowning; though the ship were no stronger than a nutshell and as leaky as an unstanched wench.
lines.annotation: Gonzalo continues his gallows joke: I guarantee the Boatswain won't drown ‚Äî even if the ship were as flimsy as a nutshell with holes in it.

lines.text: Lay her a-hold, a-hold! Set her two courses off to sea again; lay her off.
lines.annotation: 'Lay her a-hold' ‚Äî steer close to the wind to avoid being driven onto rocks. 'Two courses' refers to the two lowest sails. A last attempt to maneuver clear.

lines.text: Enter Mariners, soaking wet.
lines.annotation: The drenched sailors come up from below ‚Äî a signal that the ship is already taking on water.

lines.text: All lost! To prayers, to prayers! All lost!
lines.annotation: When the crew abandons seamanship for prayer, the situation is truly hopeless ‚Äî or seems so.

lines.text: What, must our mouths be cold?
lines.annotation: A grim idiom: 'must we already be dead?' Cold mouths = corpses. He may be refusing to give up, or checking whether things are really as lost as the mariners say.

lines.text: The King and Prince at prayers! Let's assist them, for our case is as theirs.
lines.annotation: Gonzalo reports that Alonso and Ferdinand are praying below and urges the others to join them.

lines.text: I'm out of patience.
lines.annotation: Sebastian's short temper resurfaces here ‚Äî it becomes significant in Act II.

lines.text: We are merely cheated of our lives by drunkards. This wide-chapped rascal ‚Äî would thou might'st lie drowning the washing of ten tides!
lines.annotation: 'Wide-chapped' means big-mouthed. 'The washing of ten tides' was the punishment for pirates ‚Äî hanged at low water and left until three tides had washed over the body.

lines.text: He'll be hanged yet, though every drop of water swear against it and gape at widest to glut him.
lines.annotation: Gonzalo holds to his gallows joke: the Boatswain is fated to hang, not drown ‚Äî so every wave that tries to swallow him is wasting its time.

lines.text: A confused noise within: 'Mercy on us!' ‚Äî 'We split, we split!' ‚Äî 'Farewell, my wife and children!' ‚Äî 'Farewell, brother!' ‚Äî 'We split, we split, we split!'
lines.annotation: 'We split' ‚Äî the hull is breaking apart.

lines.text: Let's all sink with the King.
Let's take leave of him.
lines.annotation: 'Take leave' carries a double meaning ‚Äî farewell before dying, but also a parting with darker implications that emerge in Act II.

lines.text: Exeunt Antonio and Sebastian.
lines.annotation: They leave Gonzalo alone onstage ‚Äî the last man standing.

lines.text: Now would I give a thousand furlongs of sea for an acre of barren ground, long heath, brown furze, any thing. The wills above be done! But I would fain die a dry death.
lines.annotation: 'Long heath, brown furze' ‚Äî thorny, useless moorland. Any solid ground at all. 'The wills above be done' ‚Äî he surrenders to Providence, but would still rather not die wet.

lines.text: Exeunt. End of Act I, Scene 1.
lines.annotation: The ship goes down ‚Äî or seems to. Scene 2 opens on the island, where Prospero tells Miranda (and the audience) the truth: the tempest was his doing, and no one was harmed.

lines.text: Act I, Scene 2 ‚Äî Before Prospero's cell. Enter Prospero and Miranda.
lines.annotation: The island. Prospero's 'cell' is a rough dwelling ‚Äî cave or hut. He and Miranda have been watching the storm from a clifftop.

lines.text: If by your art, my dearest father, you have put the wild waters in this roar, allay them.
The sky, it seems, would pour down stinking pitch, but that the sea, mounting to the welkin's cheek, dashes the fire out.
lines.annotation: 'Welkin' is the sky. She's describing lightning being quenched by waves.

lines.text: O, I have suffered with those that I saw suffer! A brave vessel, who had, no doubt, some noble creature in her, dashed all to pieces.
O, the cry did knock against my very heart! Poor souls, they perished.
Had I been any god of power, I would have sunk the sea within the earth or ere it should the good ship so have swallowed.
Be collected. No more amazement. Tell your piteous heart there's no harm done.
O, woe the day!
No harm. I have done nothing but in care of thee ‚Äî of thee, my dear one, thee, my daughter.
Thou art ignorant of what thou art, knowing nothing of whence I came, nor that I am more than Prospero, master of a poor cell, and thy no greater father.
lines.annotation: He's about to tell her who they really are ‚Äî something he's withheld until now. She has grown up knowing him only as her father and teacher, not as a displaced duke.

lines.text: More to know did never meddle with my thoughts.
'Tis time I should inform thee farther. Lend thy hand, and pluck my magic garment from me.
He removes his magic cloak and sets it aside.
lines.annotation: The cloak is the visual sign of his power. Taking it off is a deliberate gesture ‚Äî what follows is father to daughter, not magician to student.

lines.text: Lie there, my art. Wipe thou thine eyes; have comfort. The direful spectacle of the wreck, which touched the very virtue of compassion in thee, I have with such provision in mine art so safely ordered that there is no soul ‚Äî no, not so much perdition as a hair betid to any creature in the vessel.
lines.annotation: 'Not so much perdition as a hair' ‚Äî not a single hair lost. He promises no one was harmed. The audience learns this here too.

lines.text: Sit down; for thou must now know farther.
You have often begun to tell me what I am, but stopped and left me to a bootless inquisition, concluding: 'Stay, not yet.'
lines.annotation: 'Bootless inquisition' ‚Äî a fruitless inquiry, questions that led nowhere.

lines.text: The hour's now come; the very minute bids thee ope thine ear. Obey, and be attentive.
Canst thou remember a time before we came unto this cell? I do not think thou canst, for then thou wast not out three years old.
Certainly, sir, I can.
By what? By any other house or person? Of any thing the image tell me that hath kept with thy remembrance.
'Tis far off; and rather like a dream than an assurance that my remembrance warrants. Had I not four or five women once that tended me?
Thou hadst, and more, Miranda. But how is it that this lives in thy mind? What seest thou else in the dark backward and abysm of time?
lines.annotation: 'The dark backward and abysm of time' ‚Äî the past as a dark gulf.

lines.text: I do not further know.
Twelve year since, Miranda, twelve year since, thy father was the Duke of Milan and a prince of power.
Sir, are not you my father?
Thy mother was a piece of virtue, and she said thou wast my daughter; and thy father was Duke of Milan; and his only heir a princess ‚Äî no worse issued.
O the heavens! What foul play had we that we came from thence? Or blessed was't we did?
Both, both, my girl. By foul play, as thou say'st, were we heaved thence; but blessedly holp hither.
lines.annotation: 'Holp' is an archaic past tense of 'helped.' Foul play got them expelled; providence brought them here.

lines.text: O, my heart bleeds to think o' the teen that I have turned you to, which is from my remembrance! Please you, farther.
lines.annotation: 'Teen' means grief or injury.

lines.text: My brother and thy uncle, called Antonio ‚Äî I pray thee mark me ‚Äî that a brother should be so perfidious!
He whom next thyself I loved, and to him put the manage of my state; as at that time through all the signories it was the first, and Prospero the prime duke.
lines.annotation: 'Signories' ‚Äî the city-states of northern Italy. Milan was among the most powerful.

lines.text: I, thus neglecting worldly ends, all dedicated to closeness and the bettering of my mind with that which, but by being so retired, o'er-prized all popular rate ‚Äî
lines.annotation: He admits it freely: he was buried in his books, neglecting the actual business of governing. His own obsession opened the door for Antonio.

lines.text: ‚Äî in my false brother awaked an evil nature. He made such a sinner of his memory, to credit his own lie, he did believe he was indeed the Duke.
lines.annotation: Antonio told the lie so many times and exercised power so long that he convinced himself it was rightfully his.

lines.text: Your tale, sir, would cure deafness.
To have no screen between this part he played and him he played it for, he needs will be absolute Milan. Me, poor man ‚Äî my library was dukedom large enough.
lines.annotation: 'Absolute Milan' ‚Äî Antonio wanted the title itself, not just the power. Prospero's counter is rueful: for him, his books were kingdom enough. He's self-aware about his own culpability.

lines.text: He did make a treaty with the King of Naples to give him annual tribute, to do him homage, and to bend the dukedom yet unbowed ‚Äî alas, poor Milan! ‚Äî to most ignoble stooping.
lines.annotation: Antonio's deal with the King of Naples: he'd hand over Milan's independence (making it a vassal state) in exchange for military backing to seize the dukedom.

lines.text: O the heavens!
Mark his condition and the event; then tell me if this might be a brother.
I should sin to think but nobly of my grandmother. Good wombs have borne bad sons.
Now the condition. This King of Naples, being an enemy to me inveterate, hearkens my brother's suit; which was, that he in lieu o' the premises ‚Äî

‚Äî should presently extirpate me and mine out of the dukedom and confer fair Milan with all the honours on my brother. Whereon, a treacherous army levied, one midnight fated to the purpose did Antonio open the gates of Milan.
lines.annotation: 'Extirpate' ‚Äî to uproot, wipe out. Soldiers came in the night. Prospero and baby Miranda were expelled.

lines.text: Wherefore did they not that hour destroy us?
Dear, they durst not; so dear the love my people bore me. Antonio did not dare to kill us openly ‚Äî the blood it would have caused.
In few, they hurried us aboard a bark, bore us some leagues to sea; where they prepared a rotten carcass of a butt, not rigged, nor tackle, sail, nor mast ‚Äî the very rats instinctively had quit it.
lines.annotation: 'A bark' is a small boat. 'A butt' is a barrel or tub ‚Äî barely a vessel at all. They were set adrift to die at sea without technically being murdered.

lines.text: Alack, what trouble was I then to you!
O, a cherubin thou wast that did preserve me. Thou didst smile, infused with a fortitude from heaven, when I have decked the sea with drops full salt, under my burthen groaned.
lines.annotation: Her infant smile was what kept him going. He wept; she, unknowingly, gave him courage.

lines.text: By Providence divine, some food we had and some fresh water that a noble Neapolitan, Gonzalo, out of his charity ‚Äî who being then appointed master of this design ‚Äî did give us.
lines.annotation: Gonzalo was tasked with overseeing the exile but secretly provided food, water, and Prospero's books.

lines.text: Knowing I loved my books, he furnished me from mine own library with volumes that I prize above my dukedom.
Would I might but ever see that man!

Now I arise. Sit still, and hear the last of our sea-sorrow. Here in this island we arrived; and here have I, thy schoolmaster, made thee more profit than other princes' can that have more time for vainer hours.
Heavens thank you for't! And now, I pray you, sir ‚Äî for still 'tis beating in my mind ‚Äî your reason for raising this sea-storm?
Know thus far forth: by accident most strange, bountiful Fortune hath mine enemies brought to this shore.
And by my prescience I find my zenith doth depend upon a most auspicious star, whose influence if now I court not but omit, my fortunes will ever after droop. Here cease more questions.
lines.annotation: He's been watching the stars, waiting for this moment. The opportunity to reclaim his dukedom has finally arrived ‚Äî and if he misses it, it won't come again.

lines.text: Thou art inclined to sleep; 'tis a good dulness, and give it way. I know thou canst not choose.
lines.annotation: He puts her to sleep with his magic ‚Äî she has no choice in the matter.

lines.text: Miranda sleeps. Enter Ariel.
lines.annotation: Ariel is a spirit ‚Äî airy, swift, neither male nor female, capable of taking any form. Often played in productions as something between human and elemental.

lines.text: All hail, great master! Grave sir, hail! I come to answer thy best pleasure; be't to fly, to swim, to dive into the fire, to ride on the curled clouds. To thy strong bidding task Ariel and all his quality.
Hast thou, spirit, performed to point the tempest that I bade thee?
To every article. I boarded the King's ship; now on the beak, now in the waist, the deck, in every cabin I flamed amazement.
lines.annotation: 'Flamed amazement' ‚Äî Ariel appeared as St. Elmo's fire, the eerie electrical glow sometimes seen on ships' masts in storms. Sailors saw it as an omen.

lines.text: Sometimes I'd divide, and burn in many places ‚Äî on the topmast, the yards, and bowsprit would I flame distinctly, then meet and join.

Jove's lightning, the precursors o' the dreadful thunder-claps, more momentary and sight-outrunning were not. The fire and cracks of sulphurous roaring the most mighty Neptune seemed to besiege, and make his bold waves tremble.
lines.annotation: Neptune ‚Äî Roman god of the sea.

lines.text: My brave spirit! Who was so firm, so constant, that this coil would not infect his reason?
lines.annotation: 'Coil' ‚Äî uproar, commotion.

lines.text: Not a soul but felt a fever of the mad and played some tricks of desperation. All but mariners plunged in the foaming brine and quit the vessel, then all afire with me.
The King's son, Ferdinand, with hair up-staring ‚Äî then like reeds, not hair ‚Äî was the first man that leaped, cried 'Hell is empty, and all the devils are here!'
lines.annotation: Ferdinand's cry as he leapt into the sea. He becomes central to the plot shortly.

lines.text: Why, that's my spirit! But was not this nigh shore?
Close by, my master.
But are they, Ariel, safe?
Not a hair perished; on their sustaining garments not a blemish, but fresher than before. And, as thou bad'st me, in troops I have dispersed them 'bout the isle.
lines.annotation: Everyone is safe and their clothes are magically clean ‚Äî as if the storm never happened. The shipwrecked groups have been scattered around the island by design.

lines.text: The King's son have I landed by himself, whom I left cooling of the air with sighs in an odd angle of the isle, and sitting, his arms in this sad knot.
lines.annotation: Ferdinand is alone, grieving ‚Äî arms folded, believing his father drowned. Ariel placed him there deliberately.

lines.text: Of the King's ship, the mariners say how thou hast disposed, and all the rest o' the fleet.
Safely in harbour is the King's ship; in the deep nook, where once thou call'dst me up at midnight to fetch dew from the still-vexed Bermoothes, there she's hid.
lines.annotation: 'The still-vexed Bermoothes' ‚Äî Bermuda, famous for its treacherous storms. A direct nod to the real 1609 Sea Venture wreck that partly inspired the play.

lines.text: The mariners all under hatches stowed; who, with a charm joined to their suffered labour, I have left asleep.

And for the rest o' the fleet which I dispersed, they all have met again and are upon the Mediterranean flote, bound sadly home for Naples, supposing that they saw the King's ship wrecked and his great person perish.
lines.annotation: The rest of the fleet has sailed on, believing the King dead. No rescue is coming.

lines.text: Ariel, thy charge exactly is performed; but there's more work.
Is there more toil? Since thou dost give me pains, let me remember thee what thou hast promised, which is not yet performed me.
How now? Moody? What is't thou canst demand?
My liberty.
Before the time be out? No more!
I prithee, remember I have done thee worthy service; told thee no lies, made thee no mistakings, served without grudge or grumblings. Thou did promise to bate me a full year.
lines.annotation: 'Bate' ‚Äî to reduce or subtract. To take a year off his service.

lines.text: Dost thou forget from what a torment I did free thee?
No.
Thou liest, malignant thing! Hast thou forgot the foul witch Sycorax, who with age and envy was grown into a hoop? Hast thou forgot her?
lines.annotation: Sycorax was a witch banished to the island before Prospero arrived. She is Caliban's mother and the one who originally imprisoned Ariel.

lines.text: No, sir.
Thou hast. Where was she born? Speak; tell me.
Sir, in Argier.
lines.annotation: Argier ‚Äî Algiers. Sycorax was banished from North Africa, spared execution because she was pregnant (with Caliban).

lines.text: O, was she so? I must once in a month recount what thou hast been, which thou forget'st.
This damned witch Sycorax, for mischiefs manifold and sorceries terrible to enter human hearing, from Argier, thou know'st, was banished ‚Äî for one thing she did they would not take her life.

This blue-eyed hag was hither brought with child, and here was left by the sailors. Thou, my slave, as thou report'st thyself, wast then her servant; and, for thou wast a spirit too delicate to act her earthy and abhorred commands, refusing her grand hests ‚Äî
lines.annotation: 'Grand hests' ‚Äî great commands. Ariel refused to do Sycorax's darkest bidding.

lines.text: ‚Äî she did confine thee, by help of her more potent ministers and in her most unmitigable rage, into a cloven pine; within which rift imprisoned thou didst painfully remain a dozen years.
lines.annotation: Imprisoned inside a split pine tree for twelve years. Sycorax died, leaving Ariel trapped with no one able to free him.

lines.text: Within which rift imprisoned, thou didst painfully remain; and then it was when first I arrived, I made thee free.
I thank thee, master.
If thou more murmur'st, I will rend an oak and peg thee in his knotty entrails till thou hast howled away twelve winters.
lines.annotation: The threat beneath the gratitude. Prospero is not kind to Ariel when pushed ‚Äî he'd do exactly what Sycorax did.

lines.text: Pardon, master. I will be correspondent to command and do my spiriting gently.
Do so; and after two days I will discharge thee.
That's my noble master! What shall I do? Say what; what shall I do?
Go make thyself like a nymph o' the sea. Be subject to no sight but mine; invisible to every eyeball else.
Go hence with diligence.
Exit Ariel. Prospero wakes Miranda.
Awake, dear heart, awake! Thou hast slept well; awake!
The strangeness of your story put heaviness in me.
Shake it off. Come on; we'll visit Caliban my slave, who never yields us kind answer.
'Tis a villain, sir, I do not love to look on.
But, as 'tis, we cannot miss him: he does make our fire, fetch our wood, and serves in offices that profit us.
What, ho! Slave! Caliban! Thou earth, thou! Speak.
There's wood enough within.
Come forth, I say! There's other business for thee: come, thou tortoise!
Enter Ariel, dressed as a sea-nymph.
Fine apparition! My quaint Ariel, hark in thine ear.
My lord, it shall be done.
Exit Ariel. Enter Caliban.
As wicked dew as e'er my mother brushed with raven's feather from unwholesome fen drop on you both! A south-west blow on ye and blister you all o'er!
lines.annotation: Caliban enters cursing. 'Wicked dew' ‚Äî a kind of magical poison.

lines.text: For this, be sure, tonight thou shalt have cramps, side-stitches that shall pen thy breath up; urchins shall, for that vast of night that they may work, all exercise on thee.
lines.annotation: 'Urchins' ‚Äî hedgehogs or goblins. Prospero counters the curse with his own ‚Äî pain delivered through spirits in the night.

lines.text: I must eat my dinner. This island's mine, by Sycorax my mother, which thou tak'st from me.
lines.annotation: The heart of Caliban's grievance: the island was his inheritance, passed down from his mother Sycorax.

lines.text: When thou cam'st first, thou strok'st me and made much of me; wouldst give me water with berries in't, and teach me how to name the bigger light, and how the less, that burn by day and night.
And then I loved thee and showed thee all the qualities o' the isle: the fresh springs, brine-pits, barren place and fertile.
Cursed be I that did so! All the charms of Sycorax, toads, beetles, bats, light on you! For I am all the subjects that you have, which first was mine own king.
lines.annotation: He was free and is now enslaved. He taught Prospero everything about the island and got subjugation in return.

lines.text: Thou poisonous slave, got by the devil himself upon thy wicked dam ‚Äî come forth!
You taught me language, and my profit on't is, I know how to curse. The red plague rid you for learning me your language!
lines.annotation: Language was given as a gift and a tool of control ‚Äî the only use left to Caliban is cursing the giver. Post-colonial critics have written extensively on this line.

lines.text: Hag-seed, hence! Fetch us in fuel; and be quick, thou'rt best, to answer other business. Shrug'st thou, malice? If thou neglect'st or dost unwillingly what I command, I'll rack thee with old cramps, fill all thy bones with aches, make thee roar that beasts shall tremble at thy din.
I must obey: his art is of such power, it would control my dam's god, Setebos, and make a vassal of him.
lines.annotation: 'Setebos' ‚Äî the god worshipped by Sycorax and Caliban. Prospero's power exceeds even that.

lines.text: Exit Caliban. Ariel enters, leading Ferdinand with music.
lines.annotation: Ariel draws Ferdinand toward Prospero's cell with invisible music ‚Äî one of several moments where Prospero uses art (music, illusion) as a means of control.

lines.text: Come unto these yellow sands, and then take hands; curtsied when you have and kissed the wild waves whist; foot it featly here and there, and sweet sprites bear the burthen.
lines.annotation: 'Whist' means hushed or stilled. 'Foot it featly' ‚Äî dance nimbly. Ariel's song calms Ferdinand's grief and draws him toward Miranda.

lines.text: Hark, hark! Bow-wow. The watchdogs bark! Bow-wow. Hark, hark! I hear the strain of strutting chanticleer cry, 'Cock-a-diddle-dow!'
Where should this music be? I' the air or the earth? It sounds no more; and sure it waits upon some god o' the island.
Full fathom five thy father lies; of his bones are coral made; those are pearls that were his eyes: nothing of him that doth fade but doth suffer a sea-change into something rich and strange.
lines.annotation: 'Sea-change into something rich and strange' ‚Äî Ferdinand believes his father has drowned and been transformed by the sea.

lines.text: Sea-nymphs hourly ring his knell: hark! now I hear them ‚Äî ding-dong, bell.
The ditty does remember my drowned father. This is no mortal business, nor no sound that the earth owes.
Prospero and Miranda observe Ferdinand approaching.
What is't? A spirit? Lord, how it looks about! Believe me, sir, it carries a brave form. But 'tis a spirit.
lines.annotation: Miranda has only ever seen Prospero and Caliban. Ferdinand is, to her, almost incomprehensibly beautiful ‚Äî she assumes he must be supernatural.

lines.text: No, wench; it eats and sleeps and hath such senses as we have, such. This gallant which thou seest was in the wreck; and, but he's something stained with grief, that's beauty's canker, thou mightst call him a goodly person.
I might call him a thing divine, for nothing natural I ever saw so noble.
It goes on, I see, as my soul prompts it.
lines.annotation: Aside ‚Äî this is going exactly to plan.

lines.text: Most sure, the goddess on whom these airs attend! Vouchsafe my prayer may know if you remain upon this island; and that you will some good instruction give how I may bear me here.
lines.annotation: Ferdinand takes Miranda for a goddess ‚Äî neither has ever encountered anyone like the other.

lines.text: How? The best? What wert thou, if the King of Naples heard thee?

A single thing, as I am now, that wonders to hear thee speak of Naples. He does hear me; and that he does I weep: myself am Naples, who with mine eyes, never since at ebb, beheld the King my father wrecked.
lines.annotation: 'Myself am Naples' ‚Äî I am now the King of Naples. He believes his father has drowned, making him king. He weeps as he says it.

lines.text: Alack, for mercy!
Yes, faith, and all his lords, the Duke of Milan and his brave son being twain.
lines.annotation: Ferdinand believes Antonio's son also perished. (Antonio has no son in the play ‚Äî a minor inconsistency.)

lines.text: The Duke of Milan and his more braver daughter could control thee, if now 'twere fit to do't.
lines.annotation: Aside ‚Äî Prospero correcting Ferdinand's wrong information without revealing himself yet.

lines.text: My spirits, as in a dream, are all bound up. My father's loss, the weakness which I feel, the wreck of all my friends, nor this man's threats to whom I am subdued, are but light to me, might I but through my prison once a day behold this maid.
All corners else o' the earth let liberty make use of; space enough have I in such a prison.
It works.
Come on. Thou hast done well, fine Ariel! Follow me. Hark what thou else shalt do me.
Be of comfort; my father's of a better nature, sir, than he appears by speech: this is unwonted which now came from him.
Thou shalt be as free as mountain winds; but then exactly do all points of my command.
To the syllable.
Come, follow. Speak not for him.
Exeunt. End of Act I, Scene 2.
lines.annotation: The longest scene in the play ends with everything set in motion: the nobles are scattered on the island, Ferdinand and Miranda are in love at first sight, and Prospero ‚Äî pulling strings the whole time ‚Äî has his enemies exactly where he wants them.

lines.text: Act II, Scene 1 ‚Äî Another part of the island.
Alonso, Sebastian, Antonio, Gonzalo, Adrian, Francisco, and others.
Beseech you, sir, be merry. You have cause ‚Äî so have we all ‚Äî of joy; for our escape is much beyond our loss.

Our hint of woe is common: every day some sailor's wife, the masters of some merchant, and the merchant, have just our theme of woe. But for the miracle, I mean our preservation, few in millions can speak like us.
lines.annotation: Gonzalo's logic: grief is ordinary, survival this miraculous is not.

lines.text: Prithee, peace.
He receives comfort like cold porridge.
lines.annotation: An aside to Antonio ‚Äî the two of them will snipe at Gonzalo throughout this scene.

lines.text: The visitor will not give him o'er so.
lines.annotation: 'Visitor' ‚Äî a visitor to the sick, one who offers spiritual comfort. Antonio's being sardonic.

lines.text: Look, he's winding up the watch of his wit; by and by it will strike.
Sir ‚Äî
One. Tell.
When every grief is entertained that's offered, comes to the entertainer ‚Äî
A dollar.
Dolour comes to him, indeed. You have spoken truer than you purposed.
lines.annotation: 'Dolour' means grief ‚Äî Gonzalo turns Sebastian's interruption back on him. Dollar / dolour was a familiar pun.

lines.text: You have taken it wiselier than I meant you should.
Therefore, my lord ‚Äî
Fie, what a spendthrift is he of his tongue!
I prithee, spare.
Well, I have done. But yet ‚Äî
He will be talking.
The air breathes upon us here most sweetly.
As if it had lungs, and rotten ones.
Or as 'twere perfumed by a fen.
Here is everything advantageous to life.
True; save means to live.
Of that there's none, or little.
How lush and lusty the grass looks! How green!
The ground indeed is tawny.
With an eye of green in't.
He misses not much.
No; he doth but mistake the truth totally.
But the rarity of it is ‚Äî which is indeed almost beyond credit ‚Äî
As many vouched rarities are.
That our garments, being, as they were, drenched in the sea, hold notwithstanding their freshness and glosses, being rather new-dyed than stained with salt water.
If but one of his pockets could speak, would it not say he lies?
Ay, or very falsely pocket up his report.
Methinks our garments are now as fresh as when we put them on first in Afric, at the marriage of the king's fair daughter Claribel to the King of Tunis.
lines.annotation: The wedding that brought them here ‚Äî Alonso's daughter married a North African king, which many at court opposed.

lines.text: Twas a sweet marriage, and we prosper well in our return.
Tunis was never graced before with such a paragon to their queen.
Not since widow Dido's time.
lines.annotation: Dido ‚Äî queen of Carthage, near modern Tunis, abandoned by Aeneas.

lines.text: Widow! A pox o' that! How came that widow in? Widow Dido!
What if he had said 'widower Aeneas' too? Good Lord, how you take it!
Widow Dido said you? You make me study of that: she was of Carthage, not of Tunis.
This Tunis, sir, was Carthage.
Carthage?
I assure you, Carthage.
His word is more than the miraculous harp.
lines.annotation: The harp of Amphion built the walls of Thebes. Antonio is saying Gonzalo's words can conjure whole cities out of nothing.

lines.text: He hath raised the wall and houses too.
What impossible matter will he make easy next?
I think he will carry this island home in his pocket and give it his son for an apple.
And, sowing the kernels of it in the sea, bring forth more islands.
Ay.
Why, in good time.
lines.annotation: Gonzalo notices that Alonso is barely present ‚Äî lost in grief.

lines.text: Sir, we were talking that our garments seem now as fresh as when we were at Tunis at the marriage of your daughter, who is now queen.
And the rarest that e'er came there.
Bate, I beseech you, widow Dido.
lines.annotation: 'Bate' ‚Äî except. Sarcastically conceding Dido as the one exception.

lines.text: O, widow Dido! Ay, widow Dido.
Is not, sir, my doublet as fresh as the first day I wore it? I mean, in a sort.
That sort was well fished for.
When I wore it at your daughter's marriage?
You cram these words into mine ears against the stomach of my sense.
lines.annotation: He's being force-fed comfort he can't absorb. Alonso only made this sea voyage because of Claribel's wedding; now he's lost his son.

lines.text: Would I had never married my daughter there! For, coming thence, my son is lost; and, in my rate, she too, who is so far from Italy removed I ne'er again shall see her.
O thou mine heir of Naples and of Milan, what strange fish hath made his meal on thee?
Sir, he may live. I saw him beat the surges under him, and ride upon their backs; he trod the water, whose enmity he flung aside, and breasted the surge most swoll'n that met him.
lines.annotation: Francisco has almost no other lines in the play ‚Äî he exists to give this one speech of hope.

lines.text: His bold head 'bove the contentious waves he kept, and oared himself with his good arms in lusty stroke to the shore, that o'er his wave-worn basis bowed, as stooping to relieve him.
No, no, he's gone.
Sir, you may thank yourself for this great loss, that would not bless our Europe with your daughter, but rather loose her to an African.
lines.annotation: Sebastian twists the knife ‚Äî blaming Alonso for arranging the match against courtly wishes.

lines.text: Where she at least is banished from your eye, who hath cause to wet the grief on't.
Prithee, peace.
You were kneeled to and importuned otherwise by all of us, and the fair soul herself weighed between loathness and obedience, at which end o' the beam should bow.
lines.annotation: Even Claribel herself was reluctant ‚Äî Alonso forced the marriage.

lines.text: We have lost your son, I fear, for ever. Milan and Naples have more widows in them of this business' making than we bring men to comfort them: the fault's your own.
So is the dear'st o' the loss.
My lord Sebastian, the truth you speak doth lack some gentleness and time to speak it in. You rub the sore when you should bring the plaster.
lines.annotation: He doesn't deny the truth, just the cruelty of its timing.

lines.text: Very well.
And most chirurgeonly.
lines.annotation: 'Chirurgeonly' ‚Äî surgically. More mockery.

lines.text: It is foul weather in us all, good sir, when you are cloudy.
Foul weather?
Very foul.
Had I plantation of this isle, my lord ‚Äî
lines.annotation: 'Plantation' ‚Äî colonisation, settlement.

lines.text: He'd sow't with nettle-seed.
Or docks, or mallows.
And were the king on't, what would I do?
Scape being drunk for want of wine.
I' the commonwealth I would by contraries execute all things: for no kind of traffic would I admit; no name of magistrate; letters should not be known; riches, poverty, and use of service, none;
lines.annotation: Gonzalo's utopian fantasy, drawn from Montaigne's essay 'Of the Cannibals' ‚Äî a world without property, hierarchy, or labour.

lines.text: Contract, succession, bourn, bound of land, tilth, vineyard, none; no use of metal, corn, or wine, or oil; no occupation; all men idle, all; and women too, but innocent and pure;
No sovereignty ‚Äî
Yet he would be king on't.
The latter end of his commonwealth forgets the beginning.

All things in common nature should produce without sweat or endeavour: treason, felony, sword, pike, knife, gun, or need of any engine, would I not have; but nature should bring forth, of its own kind, all foison, all abundance, to feed my innocent people.
lines.annotation: 'Foison' ‚Äî plenty, abundance.

lines.text: No marrying 'mong his subjects?
None, man; all idle: whores and knaves.
I would with such perfection govern, sir, to excel the golden age.
lines.annotation: The 'Golden Age' ‚Äî a classical myth of a peaceful era before civilisation's corruptions.

lines.text: Save his majesty!
Long live Gonzalo!
And ‚Äî do you mark me, sir?
Prithee, no more: thou dost talk nothing to me.
I do well believe your highness; and did it to minister occasion to these gentlemen, who are of such sensible and nimble lungs that they always use to laugh at nothing.
lines.annotation: Gonzalo quietly reveals he knew he was being mocked ‚Äî and was performing partly to distract Alonso.

lines.text: Twas you we laughed at.
Who in this kind of merry fooling am nothing to you: so you may continue and laugh at nothing still.
What a blow was there given!
An it had not fallen flat-long.
You are gentlemen of brave mettle; you would lift the moon out of her sphere, if she would continue in it five weeks without changing.
Ariel enters, invisible, playing solemn music.
We would so, and then go a-bat-fowling.
lines.annotation: 'Bat-fowling' ‚Äî hunting birds at night by torchlight. Sebastian: with the moon in hand, we'd use it as a lantern for mischief.

lines.text: Nay, good my lord, be not angry.
No, I warrant you; I will not adventure my discretion so weakly. Will you laugh me asleep, for I am very heavy?
Go sleep, and hear us.
Alonso and others fall asleep, charmed by Ariel's music. Sebastian and Antonio remain awake.
What, all so soon asleep! I wish mine eyes would, with themselves, shut up my thoughts: I find they are inclined to do so.
Heavens keep you from these beasts! For he that sleeps is but the picture of death.
Gonzalo sleeps. Antonio and Sebastian alone.
What, art thou waking?
Do not omit the heavy offer of it: it seldom visits sorrow; when it doth, it is a comforter.
We two, my lord, will guard your rest; we'll be busy about you until your hour of sleep is out.
Thank you. Wondrous heavy.
My strong imagination sees a crown dropping upon thy head.
lines.annotation: Antonio's seduction begins. Sebastian is Alonso's brother ‚Äî if Alonso and Ferdinand are both dead, Sebastian is King of Naples.

lines.text: What, art thou waking?
Do you not hear me speak?

I do; and surely it is a sleepy language and thou speak'st out of thy sleep. What is it thou didst say? This is a strange repose, to be asleep with eyes wide open ‚Äî standing, speaking, moving, and yet so fast asleep.
Noble Sebastian, thou let'st thy fortune sleep ‚Äî die, rather; wink'st whiles thou art waking.
Thou dost snore distinctly; there's meaning in thy snores.
I am more serious than my custom: you must be so too, if heed me; which to do trebles thee o'er.
lines.annotation: Listen carefully and you'll become three times what you are ‚Äî i.e. King.

lines.text: Well, I am standing water.
I'll teach you how to flow.
lines.annotation: Standing water ‚Äî at the turn of the tide, going neither way. Antonio: I'll show you which way to move.

lines.text: Do so: to ebb hereditary sloth instructs me.
lines.annotation: Sebastian claims laziness as a family trait ‚Äî a self-deprecating deflection.

lines.text: O, if you but knew how you the purpose cherish whiles thus you mock it! How, in stripping it, you more invest it! Ebbing men, indeed, most often do so near the bottom run by their own fear or sloth.
lines.annotation: Antonio reads Sebastian precisely ‚Äî his mockery reveals how much he's already imagining it.

lines.text: Prithee, say on: the setting of thine eye and cheek proclaim a matter from thee, and a birth indeed which throes thee much to yield.

Thus, sir: although this lord of weak remembrance ‚Äî this, who shall scarce remember thee ‚Äî hath here almost persuaded ‚Äî for he's a spirit of persuasion, only professes to persuade ‚Äî the king's son's alive, 'tis as impossible that he's undrown'd as he that sleeps here swims.
lines.annotation: Dismissing Gonzalo ‚Äî 'weak remembrance' means he'll be forgotten, and soon dead. Antonio is also nudging: believe Ferdinand is drowned.

lines.text: I have no hope that he's undrown'd.
O, out of that 'no hope' what great hope have you! No hope that way is another way so high a hope that even ambition cannot pierce a wink beyond, but doubt discovery there.
lines.annotation: If Ferdinand is dead, hope collapses in one direction ‚Äî and opens in another.

lines.text: Will you grant with me that Ferdinand is drown'd?
He's gone.
Then, tell me, who's the next heir of Naples?
Claribel.
She that is Queen of Tunis; she that dwells ten leagues beyond man's life; she that from Naples can have no note, unless the sun were post ‚Äî the man i' the moon's too slow ‚Äî

till new-born chins be rough and razorable; she that ‚Äî from whom? We all were sea-swallow'd, though some cast again, and by that destiny to perform an act whereof what's past is prologue, what to come in yours and my discharge.
lines.annotation: 'What's past is prologue' ‚Äî everything that came before is only setup for what follows. The phrase is inscribed on the National Archives building in Washington, D.C.

lines.text: What stuff is this! How say you? 'Tis true, my brother's daughter's queen of Tunis; so is she heir of Naples; 'twixt which regions there is some space.
A space whose every cubit seems to cry out, 'How shall that Claribel measure us back to Naples? Keep in Tunis, and let Sebastian wake.'

Say this were death that now hath seized them; why, they were no worse than now they are. There be that can rule Naples as well as he that sleeps; lords that can prate as amply and unnecessarily as this Gonzalo; I myself could make a chough of as deep chat.
lines.annotation: A chough is a chattering bird ‚Äî Antonio says he could train a jackdaw to talk as much sense as Gonzalo.

lines.text: O, that you bore the mind that I do! What a sleep were this for your advancement! Do you understand me?
Methinks I do.
And how does your content tender your own good fortune?
I remember you did supplant your brother Prospero.
lines.annotation: Sebastian now names what Antonio is proposing ‚Äî and draws on the precedent Antonio himself set.

lines.text: True: and look how well my garments sit upon me; much feater than before. My brother's servants were then my fellows; now they are my men.
But, for your conscience?

Ay, sir; where lies that? If 'twere a kibe, 'twould put me to my slipper: but I feel not this deity in my bosom. Twenty consciences, that stand 'twixt me and Milan, candied be they and melt ere they molest!
lines.annotation: A kibe ‚Äî a heel blister. Antonio: conscience would only bother me if it actually hurt.

lines.text: Here lies your brother, no better than the earth he lies on, if he were that which now he's like ‚Äî that's dead; whom I, with this obedient steel, three inches of it, can lay to bed for ever;

whiles you, doing thus, to the perpetual wink for aye might put this ancient morsel, this Sir Prudence, who should not upbraid our course. For all the rest, they'll take suggestion as a cat laps milk; they'll tell the clock to any business that we say befits the hour.
lines.annotation: 'Sir Prudence' ‚Äî Gonzalo. Antonio's plan: Sebastian kills the king, he kills Gonzalo, the others are easily managed.

lines.text: Thy case, dear friend, shall be my precedent: as thou got'st Milan, I'll come by Naples. Draw thy sword: one stroke shall free thee from the tribute which thou pay'st, and I the king shall love thee.
lines.annotation: Naples has a claim over Milan ‚Äî by making Sebastian king, Antonio will owe no more tribute. Two birds, one stroke.

lines.text: Draw together: and when I rear my hand, do you the like, to fall it on Gonzalo.
O, but one word.
Ariel enters, unseen, and whispers in Gonzalo's ear.
My master through his art foresees the danger that you, his friend, are in; and sends me forth ‚Äî for else his project dies ‚Äî to keep them living.
lines.annotation: Ariel acts under Prospero's remote direction ‚Äî even now, on the island, Prospero is watching.

lines.text: Ariel sings into Gonzalo's ear, who starts awake.
Now, good angels, preserve the king!
lines.annotation: He doesn't know how close it was.

lines.text: Alonso and the others wake.
Why, how now? Ho, awake! Why are you drawn? Wherefore this ghastly looking?
What's the matter?
Whiles we stood here securing your repose, even now, we heard a hollow burst of bellowing like bulls, or rather lions: did't not wake you? It struck mine ear most terribly.
lines.annotation: Sebastian improvises instantly ‚Äî and convincingly.

lines.text: I heard nothing.
O, 'twas a din to fright a monster's ear, to make an earthquake! Sure, it was the roar of a whole herd of lions.
Heard you this, Gonzalo?

Upon mine honour, sir, I heard a humming, and that a strange one too, which did awake me. I shaked you, sir, and cried: as mine eyes opened, I saw their weapons drawn. There was a noise, that's verily.
'Tis best we stand upon our guard, or that we quit this place. Let's draw our weapons.
Lead away.
Heavens keep him from these beasts! For he is, sure, i' the island.
lines.annotation: Gonzalo is thinking of Ferdinand ‚Äî not the animals.

lines.text: Exeunt.
End of Act II, Scene 1.
Act II, Scene 2 ‚Äî Another part of the island.
Caliban enters with a burden of wood.
All the infections that the sun sucks up from bogs, fens, flats, on Prosper fall and make him by inch-meal a disease!
His spirits hear me and yet I needs must curse. But they'll nor pinch, fright me with urchin-shows, pitch me i' the mire, nor lead me, like a firebrand, in the dark out of my way, unless he bid 'em.
lines.annotation: 'Urchin-shows' ‚Äî apparitions in the shape of hedgehogs, a form of torment. Caliban knows exactly when Prospero's spirits can and cannot harm him.

lines.text: But for every trifle are they set upon me; sometime like apes that mow and chatter at me and after bite me, then like hedgehogs which lie tumbling in my barefoot way and mount their pricks at my footfall;
sometime am I all wound with adders who with cloven tongues do hiss me into madness.
Trinculo enters.
Lo, now, lo! Here comes a spirit of his, and to torment me for bringing wood in slowly. I'll fall flat; perchance he will not mind me.
Caliban lies down and hides under his cloak.

Here's neither bush nor shrub, to bear off any weather at all, and another storm brewing; I hear it sing i' the wind. Yond same black cloud, yond huge one, looks like a foul bombard that would shed his liquor.
lines.annotation: A bombard ‚Äî a large leather wine jug. The cloud looks ready to pour.

lines.text: If it should thunder as it did before, I know not where to hide my head: yond same cloud cannot choose but fall by pailfuls.
What have we here? A man or a fish? Dead or alive? A fish: he smells like a fish; a very ancient and fish-like smell; a kind of not of the newest poor-John.
lines.annotation: Poor-John ‚Äî dried, salted hake, the cheapest preserved fish.

lines.text: A strange fish! Were I in England now, as once I was, and had but this fish painted, not a holiday fool there but would give a piece of silver: there would this monster make a man; any strange beast there makes a man.
lines.annotation: Painted signs advertising freakish creatures drew paying crowds in England. 'Make a man' = make a man's fortune.

lines.text: When they will not give a doit to relieve a lame beggar, they will lay out ten to see a dead Indian.
lines.annotation: A doit ‚Äî a tiny coin. Native Americans were sometimes displayed in England as paying curiosities.

lines.text: Legged like a man! And his fins like arms! Warm o' my troth! I do now let loose my opinion, hold it no longer: this is no fish, but an islander, that hath lately suffered by a thunderbolt.
Thunder.
Alas, the storm is come again! My best way is to creep under his gaberdine; there is no other shelter hereabouts. Misery acquaints a man with strange bed-fellows.
lines.annotation: A gaberdine ‚Äî a long loose cloak. 'Misery acquaints a man with strange bedfellows' ‚Äî a proverb Shakespeare likely coined here.

lines.text: Trinculo creeps under Caliban's cloak. Stephano enters, drunk, singing.
I shall no more to sea, to sea, here shall I die ashore ‚Äî this is a very scurvy tune to sing at a man's funeral: well, here's my comfort.
Stephano drinks.
Do not torment me! Oh!
What's the matter? Have we devils here? Do you put tricks upon 's with savages and men of Ind, ha? I have not 'scaped drowning to be afeard now of your four legs.
For it hath been said, 'As proper a man as ever went on four legs cannot make him give ground'; and it shall be said so again while Stephano breathes at nostrils.
lines.annotation: The proverb should say 'two legs' ‚Äî Stephano's drunk enough to have lost count.

lines.text: The spirit torments me; oh!
This is some monster of the isle with four legs, who hath got, as I take it, an ague. Where the devil should he learn our language? I will give him some relief, if it be but for that.
If I can recover him and keep him tame, and get to Naples with him, he's a present for any emperor that ever trod on neat's leather.
lines.annotation: Neat's leather ‚Äî cowhide, i.e. ordinary shoes. Even an emperor wearing common boots would prize such a specimen.

lines.text: Do not torment me, prithee; I'll bring my wood home faster.
He's in his fit now and does not talk after the wisest. He shall taste of my bottle: if he have never drunk wine afore, it will go near to remove his fit.
Stephano!
Doth thy other mouth call me? Mercy, mercy! This is a devil, and no monster: I will leave him; I have no long spoon.
lines.annotation: 'He that sups with the devil needs a long spoon' ‚Äî proverbial. Stephano thinks the monster has two mouths and is therefore diabolical.

lines.text: Stephano! If thou beest Stephano, touch me and speak to me; for I am Trinculo ‚Äî be not afeard ‚Äî thy good friend Trinculo.
If thou beest Trinculo, come forth. I'll pull thee by the lesser legs: if any be Trinculo's legs, these are they.
Trinculo crawls out from under the cloak.

I took him to be killed with a thunder-stroke. But art thou not drown'd, Stephano? I hope now thou art not drown'd. Is the storm overblown? I hid me under the dead moon-calf's gaberdine for fear of the storm.
lines.annotation: A moon-calf ‚Äî a monstrosity thought to be created by the moon's influence. Trinculo assumed Caliban was a corpse.

lines.text: Prithee, do not turn me about; my stomach is not constant.
lines.annotation: Still seasick and drunk ‚Äî being spun around is too much.

lines.text: These be fine things, an if they be not sprites. That's a brave god and bears celestial liquor. I will kneel to him.
lines.annotation: Caliban, hearing voices and smelling wine, decides Stephano must be divine.

lines.text: How didst thou 'scape? How camest thou hither? Swear by this bottle how thou camest hither. I escaped upon a butt of sack which the sailors heaved overboard ‚Äî by this bottle, which I made of the bark of a tree with mine own hands since I was cast ashore.
lines.annotation: A butt ‚Äî a large cask. Stephano floated to shore clinging to a barrel of wine, then built a bottle from bark.

lines.text: I'll swear upon that bottle to be thy true subject; for the liquor is not earthly.
lines.annotation: Caliban swears allegiance on a bottle of wine rather than a Bible.

lines.text: Here; swear then how thou escapedst.
Swum ashore, man, like a duck: I can swim like a duck, I'll be sworn.
Here, kiss the book.
lines.annotation: Kissing the book ‚Äî swearing on a Bible. Stephano substitutes his bottle.

lines.text: Caliban drinks again.
Though thou canst swim like a duck, thou art made like a goose.
O Stephano, hast any more of this?
The whole butt, man: my cellar is in a rock by the sea-side where my wine is hid. How now, moon-calf! How does thine ague?
Hast thou not dropped from heaven?
Out o' the moon, I do assure thee. I was the man in the moon when time was.
lines.annotation: Stephano plays along ‚Äî happy to be mistaken for a divine being.

lines.text: I have seen thee in her and I do adore thee: my mistress showed me thee and thy dog and thy bush.
lines.annotation: The man in the moon was traditionally depicted with a dog and a thornbush. Caliban's mother Sycorax taught him to read the sky.

lines.text: Come, swear to that; kiss the book: I will furnish it anon with new contents. Swear.
Caliban drinks.
By this good light, this is a very shallow monster! I afeard of him? A very weak monster! The man i' the moon! A most poor credulous monster! Well drawn, monster, in good sooth!
lines.annotation: Trinculo sees exactly what's happening ‚Äî Caliban is being made a fool of ‚Äî but does nothing about it.

lines.text: I'll show thee every fertile inch o' th' island; and I will kiss thy foot: I prithee, be my god.
lines.annotation: The offer Caliban makes here ‚Äî to guide someone to the island's resources in exchange for protection ‚Äî is the same offer he first made to Prospero. It did not go well then either.

lines.text: By this light, a most perfidious and drunken monster! When's god's asleep, he'll rob his bottle.
I'll kiss thy foot; I'll swear myself thy subject.
lines.annotation: Caliban kneeling to kiss Stephano's foot mirrors what Prospero demands of him.

lines.text: Come on then; down, and swear.
I shall laugh myself to death at this puppy-headed monster. A most scurvy monster! I could find in my heart to beat him ‚Äî
Come, kiss.
But that the poor monster's in drink: an abominable monster!
I'll show thee the best springs; I'll pluck thee berries; I'll fish for thee and get thee wood enough.
lines.annotation: Almost word for word what Caliban offered Prospero when he first arrived. The island's knowledge, freely given again.

lines.text: A plague upon the tyrant that I serve! I'll bear him no more sticks, but follow thee, thou wondrous man.
A most ridiculous monster, to make a wonder of a poor drunkard!

I prithee, let me bring thee where crabs grow; and I with my long nails will dig thee pig-nuts; show thee a jay's nest and instruct thee how to snare the nimble marmoset; I'll bring thee to clustering filberts, and sometimes I'll get thee young scamels from the rock.
lines.annotation: Pig-nuts ‚Äî small edible tubers. Scamels are uncertain ‚Äî possibly a shellfish or seabird.

lines.text: Wilt thou go with me?
I prithee now, lead the way without any more talking. Trinculo, the king and all our company else being drown'd, we will inherit here.
Caliban sings drunkenly.
Farewell, master; farewell, farewell!
lines.annotation: Caliban is singing. It's the only time in the play he does ‚Äî a song of freedom from Prospero's service.

lines.text: A howling monster; a drunken monster!
No more dams I'll make for fish; nor fetch in firing at requiring; nor scrape trenching nor wash dish: 'ban, 'ban, Ca-Caliban has a new master ‚Äî get a new man!
lines.annotation: Caliban's freedom song ‚Äî a litany of Prospero's chores thrown off.

lines.text: O brave monster! Lead the way.
lines.annotation: Act II ends on this dark comedy.

lines.text: Exeunt.
End of Act II, Scene 2.
Act III, Scene 1 ‚Äî Before Prospero's cell.
Ferdinand enters, carrying a heavy log.
There be some sports are painful, and their labour delight in them sets off: some kinds of baseness are nobly undergone and most poor matters point to rich ends.
lines.annotation: Ferdinand is thinking through a paradox: even degrading work can be ennobling depending on why you do it. His log-carrying deliberately echoes Caliban's ‚Äî both set to it by Prospero.

lines.text: This my mean task would be as heavy to me as odious, but the mistress which I serve quickens what's dead and makes my labours pleasures.
O, she is ten times more gentle than her father's crabbed, and he's composed of harshness.
I must remove some thousands of these logs and pile them up, upon a sore injunction. My sweet mistress weeps when she sees me work, and says, such baseness had never like executor.
lines.annotation: Prospero has set Ferdinand to shift thousands of logs ‚Äî exactly the labour he assigns Caliban. Miranda has been watching and weeping.

lines.text: I forget: but these sweet thoughts do even refresh my labours, most busy least when I do it.
Miranda enters. Prospero follows at a distance, unseen, watching.
Alas, now, pray you, work not so hard. I would the lightning had burnt up those logs that you are enjoined to pile!
Pray, set it down and rest you. When this burns, 'twill weep for having wearied you. My father is hard at study; pray now, rest yourself ‚Äî he's safe for these three hours.
O most dear mistress, the sun will set before I shall discharge what I must strive to do.
If you'll sit down, I'll bear your logs the while: pray give me that; I'll carry it to the pile.
No, precious creature; I had rather crack my sinews, break my back, than you should such dishonour undergo, while I sit lazy by.
It would become me as well as it does you: and I should do it with much more ease; for my good will is to it, and yours it is against.
lines.annotation: The same task is lighter when freely chosen ‚Äî Miranda picks up Ferdinand's opening argument and turns it back on him.

lines.text: Poor worm, thou art infected! This visitation shows it.
lines.annotation: Prospero, aside. 'Infected' with love ‚Äî he sees it clearly and is quietly pleased. 'Worm' is tender, not contemptuous.

lines.text: You look wearily.
No, noble mistress ‚Äî 'tis fresh morning with me when you are by at night. I do beseech you ‚Äî chiefly that I might set it in my prayers ‚Äî what is your name?
Miranda. ‚Äî O my father, I have broke your hest to say so!
lines.annotation: Prospero forbade her to tell Ferdinand her name. She does it anyway, then catches herself.

lines.text: Admired Miranda! Indeed the top of admiration! worth what's dearest to the world!
lines.annotation: 'Miranda' means 'she who is to be admired' in Latin ‚Äî Ferdinand hears the name and plays on it immediately.

lines.text: Full many a lady I have eyed with best regard and many a time the harmony of their tongues hath into bondage brought my too diligent ear;
for several virtues have I liked several women; never any with so full soul, but some defect in her did quarrel with the noblest grace she owed and put it to the foil.
lines.annotation: 'Put it to the foil' ‚Äî made her virtues look worse by contrast with her flaws.

lines.text: But you, O you, so perfect and so peerless, are created of every creature's best!
I do not know one of my sex; no woman's face remember, save, from my glass, mine own.
lines.annotation: Miranda has grown up on a near-empty island. Ferdinand is ‚Äî as far as she knows ‚Äî only the third man she has ever seen.

lines.text: Nor have I seen more that I may call men than you, good friend, and my dear father. How features are abroad, I am skilless of;
but, by my modesty, the jewel in my dower, I would not wish any companion in the world but you.
Nor can imagination form a shape, besides yourself, to like of. But I prattle something too wildly and my father's precepts I therein do forget.
I am in my condition a prince, Miranda; I do think, a king ‚Äî I would, not so! ‚Äî and would no more endure this wooden slavery than to suffer the flesh-fly blow my mouth.
lines.annotation: 'I would, not so' ‚Äî he'd rather not be king, because that would mean his father drowned. He catches the dark implication mid-sentence.

lines.text: Hear my soul speak: the very instant that I saw you, did my heart fly to your service; there resides, to make me slave to it; and for your sake am I this patient log-man.
Do you love me?
O heaven, O earth, bear witness to this sound and crown what I profess with kind event if I speak true! if hollowly, invert what best is boded me to mischief!
I beyond all limit of what else i' the world do love, prize, honour you.
I am a fool to weep at what I'm glad of.
Fair encounter of two most rare affections! Heavens rain grace on that which breeds between 'em!
lines.annotation: Still aside. Prospero engineered this meeting, but what he sees is real ‚Äî he can't share their pure joy.

lines.text: Wherefore weep you?
At mine unworthiness that dare not offer what I desire to give, and much less take what I shall die to want.
lines.annotation: Miranda wants to propose but feels she shouldn't. The thing she'd 'die to want' is Ferdinand himself.

lines.text: But this is trifling; and all the more it seeks to hide itself, the bigger bulk it shows. Hence, bashful cunning!
And prompt me, plain and holy innocence! I am your wife, if you will marry me; if not, I'll die your maid. To be your fellow you may deny me; but I'll be your servant, whether you will or no.
lines.annotation: Miranda cuts through propriety and simply says it. She gives him three options and rules out the one that matters to her.

lines.text: My mistress, dearest; and I thus humble ever.
Ferdinand kneels.
My husband, then?
Ay, with a heart as willing as bondage e'er of freedom: here's my hand.
lines.annotation: As eager to be bound to her as a prisoner is to be free ‚Äî the play's theme of servitude and liberty running through even the love scene.

lines.text: And mine, with my heart in't. And now farewell till half an hour hence.
A thousand thousand!
Ferdinand and Miranda exit separately.
So glad of this as they I cannot be, who are surprised withal; but my rejoicing at nothing can be more.
lines.annotation: Prospero is moved ‚Äî but can't share their pure joy, because he's been orchestrating it all.

lines.text: I'll to my book, for yet ere supper-time must I perform much business appertaining.
Prospero exits.
End of Act III, Scene 1.
Act III, Scene 2 ‚Äî Another part of the island.
Caliban, Stephano, and Trinculo enter. Stephano carries his bottle.
Tell not me ‚Äî when the butt is out, we will drink water; not a drop before. Therefore bear up, and board 'em. Servant-monster, drink to me.
Servant-monster! The folly of this island! They say there's but five upon this isle: we are three of them; if th' other two be brained like us, the state totters.
Drink, servant-monster, when I bid thee: thy eyes are almost set in thy head.
Where should they be set else? He were a brave monster indeed, if they were set in his tail.
My man Stephano! I prithee, let me bring thee where crabs grow; and I with my long nails will dig thee pig-nuts;
show thee a jay's nest and instruct thee how to snare the nimble marmoset; I'll bring thee to clust'ring filberts, and sometimes I'll get thee young scamels from the rock.
lines.annotation: 'Scamels' is unidentified ‚Äî possibly a seabird, possibly shellfish. Editors have argued over it for four centuries.

lines.text: Wilt thou go with me?
I prithee now, lead the way without any more talking. Trinculo, the king and all our company else being drowned, we will inherit here.
Here; bear my bottle. Fellow Trinculo, we'll fill him by and by again.
Caliban sings.
Farewell, master; farewell, farewell!
A howling monster; a drunken monster!
No more dams I'll make for fish; nor fetch in firing at requiring, nor scrape trenching, nor wash dish.
lines.annotation: Trenching: wooden platters.

lines.text: 'Ban, 'Ban, Cacaliban has a new master ‚Äî get a new man!
O brave monster! Lead the way.
They walk. Caliban begins to speak more quietly.
As I told thee before, I am subject to a tyrant, a sorcerer, that by his cunning hath cheated me of the island.
Thou liest.
lines.annotation: Ariel, invisible, speaking in Trinculo's voice.

lines.text: Thou liest, thou jesting monkey thou! I would my valiant master would destroy thee! I do not lie.
Trinculo, if you trouble him any more in's tale, by this hand, I will supplant some of your teeth.
Why, I said nothing.
Mum, then, and no more. Proceed.
I say, by sorcery he got this isle; from me he got it. If thy greatness will revenge it on him ‚Äî for I know thou dar'st, but this thing dare not ‚Äî
lines.annotation: 'This thing' ‚Äî Trinculo.

lines.text: That's most certain.
Thou shalt be lord of it and I'll serve thee.
How now shall this be compassed? Canst thou bring me to the party?
Yea, yea, my lord: I'll yield him thee asleep, where thou mayst knock a nail into his head.
Thou liest; thou canst not.
lines.annotation: Ariel again, still in Trinculo's voice.

lines.text: What a pied ninny's this! Thou scurvy patch!
lines.annotation: 'Pied' and 'patch' both refer to the jester's traditional motley costume.

lines.text: I do beseech thy greatness, give him blows and take his bottle from him.
Trinculo, run into no further danger: interrupt the monster one word further, and, by this hand, I'll turn my mercy out o' doors and make a stockfish of thee.
lines.annotation: Stockfish: dried cod, beaten flat to soften it before eating.

lines.text: Why, what did I? I did nothing. I'll go farther off.
Didst thou not say he lied?
Thou liest.
lines.annotation: Ariel a third time, still in Trinculo's voice.

lines.text: Do I so? Take thou that!
Stephano hits Trinculo.
As you like this, give me the lie another time.
I did not give thee the lie. Out o' your wits and hearing too? A pox o' your bottle! This can sack and drinking do.
Ha, ha, ha!
Now, forward with your tale. Prithee, stand farther off.
Beat him enough. After a little time I'll beat him too.
Stand farther. Come, proceed.

Why, as I told thee, 'tis a custom with him, i' the afternoon to sleep: there thou mayst brain him, having first seized his books, or with a log batter his skull, or paunch him with a stake, or cut his wezand with thy knife.
lines.annotation: Wezand: the windpipe.

lines.text: Remember first to possess his books; for without them he's but a sot, as I am, nor hath not one spirit to command: they all do hate him as rootedly as I.
Burn but his books.
He has brave utensils ‚Äî for so he calls them ‚Äî which, when he has a house, he'll deck withal.

And that most deeply to consider is the beauty of his daughter; he himself calls her a nonpareil. I never saw a woman, but only Sycorax my dam and she; but she as far surpasseth Sycorax as great'st does least.
lines.annotation: Sycorax was Caliban's mother. He never knew her ‚Äî Prospero arrived on the island after her death.

lines.text: Is it so brave a lass?
Ay, lord; she will become thy bed, I warrant, and bring thee forth brave brood.
Monster, I will kill this man: his daughter and I will be king and queen ‚Äî save our graces! ‚Äî and Trinculo and thyself shall be viceroys.
Dost thou like the plot, Trinculo?
Excellent.
Give me thy hand. I am sorry I beat thee; but, while thou livest, keep a good tongue in thy head.
Within this half hour will he be asleep. Wilt thou destroy him then?
Ay, on mine honour.
This will I tell my master.
Thou mak'st me merry; I am full of pleasure. Let us be jocund ‚Äî will you troll the catch you taught me but whilere?
lines.annotation: 'But whilere': just now, a short while ago.

lines.text: At thy request, monster, I will do reason, any reason. Come on, Trinculo, let us sing.
They begin to sing. Ariel plays the same tune on a tabor and pipe, invisible.
What is this same?
This is the tune of our catch, played by the picture of Nobody.
lines.annotation: 'Nobody' was a stock comic figure ‚Äî depicted with a head and limbs but no torso. A well-known image in Elizabethan popular print.

lines.text: If thou beest a man, show thyself in thy likeness: if thou beest a devil, take't as thou list.
O, forgive me my sins!
He that dies pays all debts. I defy thee. Mercy upon us!
Art thou afeard?
No, monster, not I.
Be not afeard; the isle is full of noises, sounds and sweet airs, that give delight and hurt not.
Sometimes a thousand twangling instruments will hum about mine ears, and sometime voices that, if I then had waked after long sleep, will make me sleep again.
And then, in dreaming, the clouds methought would open and show riches ready to drop upon me that, when I waked, I cried to dream again.
This will prove a brave kingdom to me, where I shall have my music for nothing.
When Prospero is destroyed.
That shall be by and by: I remember the story.
The sound is going away; let's follow it, and after do our work.
Lead, monster; we'll follow. I would I could see this taborer; he lays it on.
Wilt come? I'll follow, Stephano.
They follow the invisible music and exit.
End of Act III, Scene 2.
Act III, Scene 3 ‚Äî Another part of the island.
Alonso, Sebastian, Antonio, Gonzalo, Adrian, Francisco, and others enter, weary.
By'r lakin, I can go no further, sir; my old bones ache: here's a maze trod indeed through forth-rights and meanders!
lines.annotation: 'By'r lakin': a mild oath, contracted from 'by our ladykin' (the Virgin Mary). Forth-rights: straight paths. Meanders: winding ones.

lines.text: By your patience, I needs must rest me.
Old lord, I cannot blame thee, who am myself attached with weariness, to the dulling of my spirits: sit down, and rest.
lines.annotation: 'Attached': seized, as by a legal writ.

lines.text: Even here I will put off my hope and keep it no longer for my flatterer: he is drowned whom thus we stray to find, and the sea mocks our frustrate search on land.
lines.annotation: Gonzalo is finally conceding that Ferdinand is dead.

lines.text: Well, let him go.
Thou dost talk nothing to me.
I do well believe your highness; and did it to minister occasion to these gentlemen, who are of such sensible and nimble lungs that they always use to laugh at nothing.
lines.annotation: Gonzalo has noticed that Antonio and Sebastian have been quietly mocking him.

lines.text: 'Twas you we laughed at.
Who in this kind of merry fooling am nothing to you: so you may continue and laugh at nothing still.
What a blow was there given!
An it had not fallen flat-long.
You are gentlemen of brave mettle; you would lift the moon out of her sphere, if she would continue in it five weeks without changing.
lines.annotation: In Ptolemaic cosmology, the moon moved in a crystalline sphere around the earth. To lift it out would be a feat of absurd, impossible strength ‚Äî Gonzalo is mocking their pretensions.

lines.text: Solemn and strange music. Prospero enters above, invisible. Strange shapes bring in a banquet, dance around it with gentle actions of salutation, and depart.
What harmony is this? My good friends, hark!
Marvellous sweet music!
Give us kind keepers, heavens! What were these?
A living drollery.
lines.annotation: 'Drollery': a puppet show, or a comic painting. Sebastian means it as a jest but is genuinely unnerved.

lines.text: Now I will believe that there are unicorns; that in Arabia there is one tree, the phoenix' throne, one phoenix at this hour reigning there.
lines.annotation: The phoenix was a legendary bird said to live in Arabia, unique and immortal, dying in fire and reborn from its own ashes. Sebastian cites it as a type of impossible thing he'd now believe.

lines.text: I'll believe both; and what does else want credit, come to me, and I'll be sworn 'tis true.
Travellers ne'er did lie, though fools at home condemn 'em.
If in Naples I should report this now, would they believe me? If I should say, I saw such islanders ‚Äî
lines.annotation: Gonzalo is thinking aloud about how his account would be received at home ‚Äî an echo of his utopian speech in Act II.

lines.text: for, certes, these are people of the island ‚Äî who, though they are of monstrous shape, yet, note, their manners are more gentle-kind than of our human generation you shall find many, nay, almost any.
Honest lord, thou hast said well; for some of you there present are worse than devils.
lines.annotation: Prospero, aside, still unseen. He is referring to Antonio and Sebastian.

lines.text: I cannot too much muse such shapes, such gesture and such sound, expressing ‚Äî although they want the use of tongue ‚Äî a kind of excellent dumb discourse.
lines.annotation: 'Muse': wonder at. 'Want': lack.

lines.text: Praise in departing.
lines.annotation: A proverb: save your praise until the end, in case things go wrong. Prospero, still aside.

lines.text: They vanished strangely.
No matter, since they have left their viands behind; for we have stomachs. Will't please you taste of what is here?
lines.annotation: Viands: food, provisions.

lines.text: Not I.
Faith, sir, you need not fear. When we were boys, who would believe that there were mountaineers dewlapped like bulls, whose throats had hanging at 'em wallets of flesh?
lines.annotation: 'Dewlapped': with loose folds of skin at the throat, like a bull's. Gonzalo is citing accounts of peoples with goitres, reported by travellers from the Alps.

lines.text: Or that there were such men whose heads stood in their breasts? Which now we find each putter-out of five for one will bring us good word of.
lines.annotation: 'Putter-out of five for one': a traveller who deposited money before a voyage, to receive five times the sum on return ‚Äî only if they survived. Gonzalo's point is that even such wild travel tales have proved true.

lines.text: I will stand to and feed, although my last: no matter, since I feel the best is past.
I will stand to and feed, although my last: no matter, since I feel the best is past.
Thunder and lightning. Ariel enters like a harpy, claps his wings upon the table, and the banquet vanishes.
You are three men of sin, whom Destiny ‚Äî that hath to instrument this lower world and what is in't ‚Äî the never-surfeited sea hath caused to belch up you;
lines.annotation: Harpies in classical mythology were winged spirits who snatched food from the living. Here the harpy removes the banquet rather than stealing it. The three men of sin are Alonso, Sebastian, and Antonio.

lines.text: and on this island where man doth not inhabit ‚Äî you 'mongst men being most unfit to live ‚Äî I have made you mad;
and even with such-like valour men hang and drown their proper selves.
lines.annotation: 'Proper': own.

lines.text: Alonso, Sebastian, and Antonio draw their swords.

You fools! I and my fellows are ministers of Fate: the elements, of whom your swords are tempered, may as well wound the loud winds, or with bemocked-at stabs kill the still-closing waters, as diminish one dowle that's in my plume.
lines.annotation: 'Dowle': a single fibre of a feather. 'Still-closing': water that closes over a wound immediately.

lines.text: My fellow-ministers are like invulnerable. If you could hurt, your swords are now too massy for your strengths and will not be uplifted.
lines.annotation: 'Massy': heavy.

lines.text: Their swords drop.
But remember ‚Äî for that's my business to you ‚Äî that you three from Milan did supplant good Prospero;

exposed unto the sea, which hath requit it, him and his innocent child: for which foul deed the powers, delaying, not forgetting, have incensed the seas and shores, yea, all the creatures, against your peace.
Thee of thy son, Alonso, they have bereft; and do pronounce by me: lingering perdition, worse than any death can be at once, shall step by step attend you and your ways;
lines.annotation: Perdition: damnation, utter ruin.

lines.text: whose wraths to guard you from ‚Äî which here, in this most desolate isle, else falls upon you ‚Äî is nothing but heart's sorrow and a clear life ensuing.
lines.annotation: The only escape from punishment is genuine remorse and a reformed life. Ariel states this as a condition, not a promise.

lines.text: Ariel vanishes in thunder. The shapes return, mock-dance, and carry out the table.
Bravely the figure of this harpy hast thou performed, my Ariel; a grace it had, devouring.
lines.annotation: Prospero, still above and unseen by the others. 'A grace it had, devouring' ‚Äî the vanishing of the banquet was itself graceful.

lines.text: Of my instruction hast thou nothing bated in what thou hadst to say: so, with good life and observation strange, my meaner ministers their several kinds have done.
lines.annotation: 'Bated': omitted. 'Meaner ministers': the lesser spirits who brought and removed the banquet.

lines.text: My high charms work and these mine enemies are all knit up in their distractions; they now are in my power;
and in these fits I leave them, while I visit young Ferdinand, whom they suppose is drowned, and his and mine loved darling.
Prospero exits.
I' the name of something holy, sir, why stand you in this strange stare?
O, it is monstrous, monstrous! Methought the billows spoke and told me of it; the winds did sing it to me, and the thunder, that deep and dreadful organ-pipe, pronounced the name of Prosper:
it did bass my trespass. Therefore my son i' the ooze is bedded; and I'll seek him deeper than e'er plummet sounded and with him there lie mudded.
