lines.annotation: 'Bass my trespass': proclaim my sin in a deep bass voice. A plummet is a lead weight on a line, used to measure water depth.

lines.text: Alonso exits.
But one fiend at a time, I'll fight their legions o'er.
I'll be thy second.
Sebastian and Antonio exit.
All three of them are desperate: their great guilt, like poison given to work a great time after, now 'gins to bite the spirits.
lines.annotation: Gonzalo identifies Alonso's grief and the sudden frenzy of Sebastian and Antonio as the same guilt working on each of them differently.

lines.text: I do beseech you that are of suppler joints, follow them swiftly and hinder them from what this ecstasy may now provoke them to.
lines.annotation: 'Ecstasy': madness, being outside oneself. From the Greek 'ekstasis'.

lines.text: Follow, I pray you!
They exit.
End of Act III, Scene 3.
Act IV, Scene 1 ‚Äî Before Prospero's cell.
Prospero, Ferdinand, and Miranda enter.
If I have too austerely punished you, your compensation makes amends, for I have given you here a third of mine own life, or that for which I live;
whom once again I tender to thy hand: all thy vexations were but my trials of thy love and thou hast strangely stood the test.
lines.annotation: 'Strangely': remarkably, extraordinarily.

lines.text: Here, afore Heaven, I ratify this my rich gift. O Ferdinand, do not smile at me that I boast her off, for thou shalt find she will outstrip all praise and make it halt behind her.
I do believe it against an oracle.
Then, as my gift and thine own acquisition worthily purchased, take my daughter: but if thou dost break her virgin-knot before all sanctimonious ceremonies may with full and holy rite be ministered,
lines.annotation: 'Sanctimonious': holy, sacred ‚Äî the word had no ironic connotation in Shakespeare's time.

lines.text: no sweet aspersion shall the heavens let fall to make this contract grow; but barren hate, sour-eyed disdain and discord shall bestrew the union of your bed with weeds so loathly that you shall hate it both.
lines.annotation: 'Aspersion': a sprinkling ‚Äî here of rain or dew, used as a metaphor for heavenly blessing.

lines.text: Therefore take heed, as Hymen's lamps shall light you.
lines.annotation: Hymen was the Greek god of marriage ceremonies. Torches were carried at Roman and Greek wedding processions.

lines.text: As I hope for quiet days, fair issue and long life, with such love as 'tis now, the murkiest den, the most opportune place, the strong'st suggestion our worser genius can, shall never melt mine honour into lust,
to take away the edge of that day's celebration when I shall think, or Phoebus' steeds are foundered, or Night kept chained below.
lines.annotation: Phoebus Apollo drove the sun across the sky in a chariot. Ferdinand means: I won't anticipate the wedding night even if the sun's horses seem to have gone lame ‚Äî i.e. even if the day drags on forever.

lines.text: Fairly spoke. Sit then and talk with her; she is thine own.
Ferdinand and Miranda sit and talk together.
What, Ariel! My industrious servant, Ariel!
Ariel enters.
What would my potent master? Here I am.
Thou and thy meaner fellows your last service did worthily perform; and I must use you in such another trick. Go bring the rabble, o'er whom I give thee power, here to this place.
lines.annotation: 'Rabble': the lesser spirits under Ariel's command.

lines.text: Incite them to quick motion; for I must bestow upon the eyes of this young couple some vanity of mine art: it is my promise, and they expect it from me.
Presently?
Ay, with a twink.
Before you can say 'come' and 'go', and breathe twice and cry 'so, so', each one, tripping on his toe, will be here with mop and mow.
lines.annotation: 'Mop and mow': grimaces and gestures.

lines.text: Do you love me, master? No?
Dearly, my delicate Ariel. Do not approach till thou dost hear me call.
Well, I conceive.
Ariel exits.
Look thou be true; do not give dalliance too much the rein: the strongest oaths are straw to the fire i' the blood.
I warrant you sir; the white cold virgin snow upon my heart abates the ardour of my liver.
lines.annotation: The liver was believed to be the seat of passionate desire.

lines.text: Well. Now come, my Ariel! Bring a corollary, rather than want a spirit.
lines.annotation: 'Corollary': a surplus, an extra. Prospero wants more spirits than needed rather than risk having too few.

lines.text: Appear, and pertly! No tongue! All eyes! Be silent.
Soft music. A masque begins. Iris enters.
lines.annotation: A masque was a form of court entertainment popular in Jacobean England, combining music, dance, allegorical figures, and elaborate staging. They were typically performed to celebrate royal occasions such as betrothals and weddings.

lines.text: Ceres, most bounteous lady, thy rich leas of wheat, rye, barley, vetches, oats and peas;
lines.annotation: Iris was the goddess of the rainbow and messenger of the gods. Ceres was the goddess of grain and harvest. Vetches: leguminous plants grown as fodder.

lines.text: thy turfy mountains, where live nibbling sheep, and flat meads thatched with stover, them to keep;
lines.annotation: 'Meads': meadows. 'Stover': dried grass or hay stored as winter fodder.

lines.text: thy banks with pion√®d and twill√®d brims, which spongy April at thy hest betrims, to make cold nymphs chaste crowns;
lines.annotation: 'Pion√®d and twill√®d': much debated ‚Äî probably meaning undercut and woven over with roots, describing eroded riverbanks reinforced by plant growth.

lines.text: and thy broom-groves, whose shadow the dismissed bachelor loves, being lass-lorn;
thy pole-clipped vineyard; and thy sea-marge, sterile and rocky-hard, where thou thyself dost air:
lines.annotation: 'Pole-clipped': pruned by poles, or with vines trained along poles. 'Sea-marge': the shoreline.

lines.text: the queen o' the sky, whose watery arch and messenger am I, bids thee leave these, and with her sovereign grace, here on this grass-plot, in this very place, to come and sport.
lines.annotation: 'The queen o' the sky': Juno, queen of the gods.

lines.text: Ceres enters.
Hail, many-coloured messenger, that ne'er dost disobey the wife of Jupiter;
who with thy saffron wings upon my flowers diffusest honey-drops, refreshing showers, and with each end of thy blue bow dost crown my bosky acres and my unshrubb'd down,
rich scarf to my proud earth; why hath thy queen summoned me hither, to this short-grassed green?
lines.annotation: 'Bosky': wooded. 'Down': open upland.

lines.text: A contract of true love to celebrate; and some donation freely to estate on the blest lovers.
lines.annotation: 'Estate': bestow, settle upon.

lines.text: Tell me, heavenly bow, if Venus or her son, as thou dost know, do now attend the queen?
lines.annotation: Venus was the goddess of love; her son Cupid. Ceres is asking whether they are present ‚Äî she has reason to distrust them.

lines.text: Of her society be not afraid: I met her deity cutting the clouds towards Paphos and her son dove-drawn with her.
lines.annotation: Paphos was a city in Cyprus, site of Venus's most famous temple. Venus's chariot was traditionally drawn by doves.

lines.text: Her waspish-headed son has broke his arrows, swears he will shoot no more but play with sparrows and be a boy right out.
lines.annotation: Cupid's arrows caused mortals to fall in love. 'Waspish-headed': irritable, bad-tempered.

lines.text: High'st queen of state, great Juno, comes; I know her by her gait.
lines.annotation: In classical tradition, gods were recognised by their characteristic bearing and movement.

lines.text: Juno descends.
lines.annotation: In staging a masque, gods and goddesses traditionally descended from above on a mechanical cloud or throne ‚Äî a piece of theatre machinery that Jacobean court audiences expected and that would have been expensive to stage.

lines.text: How does my bounteous sister? Go with me to bless this twain, that they may prosperous be and honoured in their issue.
lines.annotation: 'Issue': offspring, children.

lines.text: Juno and Ceres sing together.
Honour, riches, marriage-blessing, long continuance, and increasing, hourly joys be still upon you!
Earth's increase, foison plenty, barns and garners never empty, vines and clustering bunches growing, plants with goodly burthen bowing;
lines.annotation: 'Foison': abundance, a plentiful harvest. 'Garners': granaries.

lines.text: spring come to you at the farthest in the very end of harvest! Scarcity and want shall shun you; Ceres' blessing so is on you.
This is a most majestic vision, and harmonious charmingly. May I be bold to think these spirits?
Spirits, which by mine art I have from their confines called to enact my present fancies.
Let me live here ever; so rare a wondered father and a wise makes this place Paradise.
lines.annotation: 'Wondered': wonder-working.

lines.text: Juno and Ceres speak privately. Iris calls nymphs and reapers to join the dance.
You nymphs, called Naiads, of the windring brooks, with your sedged crowns and ever-harmless looks, leave your crisp channels and on this green land answer your summons;
lines.annotation: Naiads were freshwater nymphs in Greek mythology. 'Windring': winding. 'Sedged': made of sedge, a water plant. 'Crisp': rippling.

lines.text: Juno does command: come, temperate nymphs, and help to celebrate a contract of true love; be not too late.
Nymphs enter. Then sunburned reapers enter and join them in a dance.
Prospero starts suddenly and speaks. The dancers vanish.
I had forgot that foul conspiracy of the beast Caliban and his confederates against my life: the minute of their plot is almost come.
lines.annotation: Prospero has been so absorbed in the masque he nearly forgot the assassination plot laid out in Act III, Scene 2.

lines.text: To the spirits.
Well done! Avoid; no more!
This is most strange: your father's in some passion that works him strongly.
Never till this day saw I him touched with anger so distempered.
You do look, my son, in a moved sort, as if you were dismayed: be cheerful, sir.
Our revels now are ended. These our actors, as I foretold you, were all spirits and are melted into air, into thin air:
and, like the baseless fabric of this vision, the cloud-capped towers, the gorgeous palaces, the solemn temples, the great globe itself,
yea, all which it inherit, shall dissolve and, like this insubstantial pageant faded, leave not a rack behind.
lines.annotation: 'Rack': a wisp of cloud. 'The great globe itself' may refer to the Globe Theatre as well as the earth.

lines.text: We are such stuff as dreams are made on, and our little life is rounded with a sleep.
Sir, I am vexed; bear with my weakness; my old brain is troubled: be not disturbed with my infirmity.
If you be pleased, retire into my cell and there repose: a turn or two I'll walk, to still my beating mind.
We wish your peace.
Ferdinand and Miranda exit.
Come with a thought! I thank thee, Ariel: come.
Ariel enters.
Thy thoughts I cleave to. What's thy pleasure?
Spirit, we must prepare to meet with Caliban.
Ay, my commander: when I presented Ceres, I thought to have told thee of it, but I feared lest I might anger thee.
lines.annotation: Ariel played the role of Ceres in the masque.

lines.text: Say again, where didst thou leave these varlets?
I told you, sir, they were red-hot with drinking; so full of valour that they smote the air for breathing in their faces; beat the ground for kissing of their feet;
yet always bending towards their project. Then I beat my tabor; at which, like unbacked colts, they pricked their ears, advanced their eyelids, lifted up their noses as they smelt music:
lines.annotation: 'Unbacked': unbroken, never ridden.

lines.text: so I charmed their ears that calf-like they followed through tooth'd briers, sharp furzes, pricking goss and thorns, which entered their frail shins:
lines.annotation: 'Furzes' and 'goss' (gorse): thorny shrubs common on heathland.

lines.text: at last I left them i' the filthy-mantled pool beyond your cell, there dancing up to the chins, that the foul lake o'erstunk their feet.
lines.annotation: 'Filthy-mantled': covered with a scum of algae.

lines.text: This was well done, my bird. Thy shape invisible retain thou still: the trumpery in my house, go bring it hither, for stale to catch these thieves.
lines.annotation: 'Trumpery': showy but worthless stuff ‚Äî here, gaudy clothing. 'Stale': a decoy or lure.

lines.text: I go, I go.
Ariel exits.
A devil, a born devil, on whose nature nurture can never stick; on whom my pains, humanely taken, all, all lost, quite lost;
and as with age his body uglier grows, so his mind cankers. I will plague them all, even to roaring.
Ariel re-enters, laden with glistening apparel. He hangs it on a line.
Caliban, Stephano, and Trinculo enter, wet and muddy.
Pray you, tread softly, that the blind mole may not hear a footfall: we now are near his cell.
Monster, your fairy, which you say is a harmless fairy, has done little better than played the Jack with us.
lines.annotation: 'Played the Jack': played the knave, tricked us. 'Jack' also refers to a will-o'-the-wisp, a marsh light that led travellers astray.

lines.text: Monster, I do smell all horse-piss; at which my nose is in great indignation.
So is mine. Do you hear, monster? If I should take a displeasure against you, look you ‚Äî
Thou wert but a lost monster.
Good my lord, give me thy favour still. Be patient, for the prize I'll bring thee to shall hoodwink this mischance: therefore speak softly. All's hushed as midnight yet.
Ay, but to lose our bottles in the pool ‚Äî
There is not only disgrace and dishonour in that, monster, but an infinite loss.
That's more to me than my wetting: yet this is your harmless fairy, monster.
I will fetch off my bottle, though I be o'er ears for my labour.

Prithee, my king, be quiet. Seest thou here, this is the mouth o' the cell: no noise, and enter. Do that good mischief which may make this island thine own for ever, and I, thy Caliban, for aye thy foot-licker.
Give me thy hand. I do begin to have bloody thoughts.
O King Stephano! O peer! O worthy Stephano! Look what a wardrobe here is for thee!
lines.annotation: 'O King Stephano! O peer!' echoes a popular ballad of the period about a king named Stephano ‚Äî the joke being that Trinculo now addresses his drunken companion with the same words.

lines.text: Let it alone, thou fool; it is but trash.
O, ho, monster! We know what belongs to a frippery.
lines.annotation: 'Frippery': a second-hand clothes shop.

lines.text: Trinculo begins pulling clothes from the line.
Put off that gown, Trinculo; by this hand, I'll have that gown.
Thy grace shall have it.
The dropsy drown this fool! What do you mean to dote thus on such luggage?
lines.annotation: 'Dropsy': a disease causing extreme fluid retention and swelling. 'Luggage': here, worthless baggage.

lines.text: Let's alone and do the murder first: if he awake, from toe to crown he'll fill our skins with pinches, make us strange stuff.
Be you quiet, monster. Mistress line, is not this my jerkin?
lines.annotation: 'Jerkin': a close-fitting jacket. 'Mistress line' is the clothes-line itself, addressed as if it were a person.

lines.text: Now is the jerkin under the line: now, jerkin, you are like to lose your hair and prove a bald jerkin.
lines.annotation: A pun: sailors who crossed the equator ('the line') were said to lose their hair from fever. A jerkin without hair is just bare leather.

lines.text: Do, do: we steal by line and level, an't like your grace.
lines.annotation: 'By line and level': precisely, methodically ‚Äî a builder's phrase for working with a plumb line and spirit level. Used here as wordplay on the clothes-line.

lines.text: I thank thee for that jest; here's a garment for't: wit shall not go unrewarded while I am king of this country.
'Steal by line and level' is an excellent pass of pate; there's another garment for't.
I will have none on't: we shall lose our time, and all be turned to barnacles, or to apes with foreheads villainous low.
lines.annotation: Barnacles: barnacle geese, believed in folklore to hatch from barnacles on driftwood. Both barnacles and apes were types of degraded or enchanted transformation.

lines.text: Monster, lay-to your fingers: help to bear this away where my hogshead of wine is, or I'll turn you out of my kingdom.
And this.
Ay, and this.
A noise of hunters. Spirits in the shape of hounds enter, harrying Caliban, Stephano, and Trinculo. Prospero and Ariel set them on.
Hey, Mountain, hey!
Silver! there it goes, Silver!
Fury, Fury! there, Tyrant, there! Hark! Hark!
lines.annotation: The hounds' names ‚Äî Mountain, Silver, Fury, Tyrant ‚Äî are typical hunting dog names of the period.

lines.text: Caliban, Stephano, and Trinculo are driven out.
Go charge my goblins that they grind their joints with dry convulsions, shorten up their sinews with aged cramps, and more pinch-spotted make them than pard or cat o' mountain.
lines.annotation: 'Pard': leopard. 'Cat o' mountain': wildcat.

lines.text: Hark, they roar!
Let them be hunted soundly. At this hour lie at my mercy all mine enemies: shortly shall all my labours end, and thou shalt have the air at freedom: for a little follow, and do me service.
They exit.
End of Act IV, Scene 1.
Act V, Scene 1 ‚Äî Before Prospero's cell.
Prospero enters in his magic robes. Ariel enters with him.
Now does my project gather to a head: my charms crack not; my spirits obey; and time goes upright with his carriage.
lines.annotation: 'Time goes upright with his carriage': time carries its burden without bending ‚Äî everything is on schedule.

lines.text: How's the day?
On the sixth hour; at which time, my lord, you said our work should cease.
I did say so, when first I raised the tempest. Say, my spirit, how fares the king and 's followers?
Confined together in the same fashion as you gave in charge, just as you left them; all prisoners, sir, in the lime-grove which weather-fends your cell;
lines.annotation: 'Weather-fends': shelters from the weather.

lines.text: they cannot budge till your release. The king, his brother and yours, abide all three distracted and the remainder mourning over them, brimful of sorrow and dismay;
but chiefly him that you termed, sir, 'the good old lord Gonzalo'; his tears run down his beard, like winter's drops from eaves of reeds.
lines.annotation: 'Eaves of reeds': the overhanging edge of a thatched roof.

lines.text: Your charm so strongly works 'em that if you now beheld them, your affections would become tender.
Dost thou think so, spirit?
Mine would, sir, were I human.

And mine shall. Hast thou, which art but air, a touch, a feeling of their afflictions, and shall not myself, one of their kind, that relish all as sharply, passion as they, be kindlier moved than thou art?
Though with their high wrongs I am struck to the quick, yet with my nobler reason 'gainst my fury do I take part: the rarer action is in virtue than in vengeance.
They being penitent, the sole drift of my purpose doth extend not a frown further. Go release them, Ariel: my charms I'll break, their senses I'll restore, and they shall be themselves.
I'll fetch them, sir.
Ariel exits.
Prospero draws a circle on the ground.
Ye elves of hills, brooks, standing lakes and groves, and ye that on the sands with printless foot do chase the ebbing Neptune and do fly him when he comes back;
you demi-puppets that by moonshine do the green sour ringlets make, whereof the ewe not bites, and you whose pastime is to make midnight mushrooms,
lines.annotation: 'Green sour ringlets': fairy rings ‚Äî circles of darker grass which folklore attributed to fairies dancing. 'Midnight mushrooms': mushrooms that appear overnight, also attributed to fairy activity.

lines.text: that rejoice to hear the solemn curfew; by whose aid, weak masters though ye be, I have bedimmed the noontide sun, called forth the mutinous winds,
and 'twixt the green sea and the azured vault set roaring war: to the dread rattling thunder have I given fire and rifted Jove's stout oak with his own bolt;
lines.annotation: 'Azured vault': the blue sky. 'Rifted Jove's stout oak with his own bolt': split Jupiter's sacred oak tree with a lightning bolt ‚Äî Jupiter being the Roman god of thunder.

lines.text: the strong-based promontory have I made shake and by the spurs plucked up the pine and cedar:
graves at my command have waked their sleepers, oped, and let 'em forth by my so potent art.
lines.annotation: This speech is closely modelled on a speech by Medea in Ovid's Metamorphoses ‚Äî one of the most explicit borrowings in the play.

lines.text: But this rough magic I here abjure, and, when I have required some heavenly music, which even now I do, to work mine end upon their senses that this airy charm is for,
I'll break my staff, bury it certain fathoms in the earth, and deeper than did ever plummet sound I'll drown my book.
Solemn music. Ariel enters leading Alonso, Gonzalo, Sebastian, Antonio, Adrian, and Francisco, all charmed. They enter the circle Prospero has made and stand there.
A solemn air and the best comforter to an unsettled fancy cure thy brains, now useless, boiled within thy skull!
To Gonzalo.
There stand, for you are spell-stopped. Holy Gonzalo, honourable man, mine eyes, even sociable to the show of thine, fall fellowly drops.
lines.annotation: 'Sociable to the show of thine': sympathetic to what your eyes are showing ‚Äî Gonzalo's tears prompt Prospero's own.

lines.text: The charm dissolves apace; and as the morning steals upon the night, melting the darkness, so their rising senses begin to chase the ignorant fumes that mantle their clearer reason.
To Alonso.
Good Alonso, be well: the wrongst that I ever suffered was an injury done to thee; not a word of grief but as it wounds thee.
To Sebastian and Antonio.
Flesh and blood, you, brother mine, that entertained ambition, expelled remorse and nature; who, with Sebastian, whose inward pinches therefore are most strong, would here have killed your king;
I do forgive thee, unnatural though thou art.
Ariel helps Prospero change out of his magic robes and into the clothes of the Duke of Milan.
I will discase me, and myself present as I was sometime Milan.
lines.annotation: 'Discase': undress, shed a disguise. 'As I was sometime Milan': as I was when I was Duke of Milan.

lines.text: Quickly, spirit; thou shalt ere long be free.
Ariel sings as he helps Prospero dress.
Where the bee sucks, there suck I: in a cowslip's bell I lie; there I couch when owls do cry. On the bat's back I do fly after summer merrily.
lines.annotation: Ariel's song of anticipated freedom. Cowslip: a small yellow wildflower.

lines.text: Merrily, merrily shall I live now under the blossom that hangs on the bough.
Why, that's my dainty Ariel! I shall miss thee: but yet thou shalt have freedom: so, so, so.
To the king's ship, invisible as thou art: there shalt thou find the mariners asleep under the hatches; the master and the boatswain being awake, enforce them to this place, and presently, I prithee.
I drink the air before me, and return or ere your pulse twice beat.
Ariel exits.
All torment, trouble, wonder and amazement inhabits here: some heavenly power guide us out of this fearful country!
Behold, sir king, the wronged Duke of Milan, Prospero: for more assurance that a living prince does now speak to thee, I embrace thy body;
Prospero embraces Alonso.
and to thee and thy company I bid a hearty welcome.
Whether thou be'st he or no, or some enchanted trifle to abuse me, as late I have been, I not know: thy pulse beats as of flesh and blood;
and, since I saw thee, the affliction of my mind amends, with which, I fear, a madness held me: this must crave, an if this be at all, a most strange story.
Thy dukedom I resign and do entreat thou pardon me my wrongs. But how should Prospero be living and be here?
Be't so, first: and look thou be true; do not give dalliance too much the rein.
First, noble friend, let me embrace thine age, whose honour cannot be measured or confined.
lines.annotation: 'Thine age': your old age ‚Äî a respectful address.

lines.text: Prospero embraces Gonzalo.
Whether this be or be not, I'll not swear.
You do yet taste some subtleties o' the isle, that will not let you believe things certain.
lines.annotation: 'Subtleties': sugar confections moulded into elaborate shapes, served at banquets ‚Äî often deceptively lifelike. A play on the island's illusions.

lines.text: Welcome, my friends all!
Aside to Sebastian and Antonio.
But you, my brace of lords, were I so minded, I here could pluck his highness' frown upon you and justify you traitors: at this time I will tell no tales.
lines.annotation: 'Justify': prove, demonstrate.

lines.text: The devil speaks in him.
No.
To Antonio.
For you, most wicked sir, whom to call brother would even infect my mouth, I do forgive thy rankest fault; all of them; and require my dukedom of thee, which perforce, I know, thou must restore.
If thou be'st Prospero, give us particulars of thy preservation; how thou hast met us here, who three hours since were wracked upon this shore;
where I have lost ‚Äî how sharp the point of it! ‚Äî my dear son Ferdinand.
I am woe for't, sir.
Irreparable is the loss; and patience says it is past her cure.
I rather think you have not sought her help, of whose soft grace for the like loss I have her sovereign aid and rest myself content.
You the like loss?
As great to me as late; and, supportable to make the dear loss, have I means much weaker than you may call to comfort you, for I have lost my daughter.
A daughter? O heavens, that they were living both in Naples, the king and queen there! That they were, I wish myself were mudded in that oozy bed where my son lies.
lines.annotation: Alonso is imagining a marriage between Ferdinand and Miranda ‚Äî not knowing Ferdinand is alive.

lines.text: When did you lose your daughter?
In this last tempest.
I perceive these lords at this encounter do so much admire that they devour their reason and scarce think their eyes do offices of truth, their words are natural breath.
lines.annotation: 'Admire': wonder, be astonished. 'Do offices of truth': function accurately.

lines.text: But, howsoever you have been jostled from your senses, know for certain that I am Prospero and that very duke which was thrust forth of Milan, who most strangely upon this shore, where you were wrecked, was landed, to be the lord on't.
No more yet of this; for 'tis a chronicle of day by day, not a relation for a breakfast nor befitting this first meeting. Welcome, sir; this cell's my court:
here have I few attendants and subjects none abroad: pray you, look in.
Prospero opens the entrance to the cell. Ferdinand and Miranda are revealed inside, playing chess.
Sweet lord, you play me false.
No, my dear'st love, I would not for the world.
Yes, for a score of kingdoms you should wrangle, and I would call it fair play.
lines.annotation: Chess was a conventional image of courtship in Renaissance literature, with the game's moves standing in for negotiation between lovers.

lines.text: If this prove a vision of the island, one dear son shall I twice lose.
A most high miracle!
Though the seas threaten, they are merciful; I have cursed them without cause.
lines.annotation: Ferdinand cursed the sea when he thought it had drowned his father. He now knows his father is alive.

lines.text: Ferdinand kneels before Alonso.
Now all the blessings of a glad father compass thee about! Arise, and say how thou camest here.
O, wonder! How many goodly creatures are there here! How beauteous mankind is! O brave new world, that has such people in't!
lines.annotation: 'Brave': fine, splendid ‚Äî the standard Elizabethan sense. Miranda has grown up seeing almost no one but her father and Caliban.

lines.text: 'Tis new to thee.
What is this maid with whom thou wast at play? Your eld'st acquaintance cannot be three hours: is she the goddess that hath severed us, and brought us thus together?
Sir, she is mortal; but by immortal Providence she's mine: I chose her when I could not ask my father for his approbation.
She is daughter to this famous Duke of Milan, of whom so often I have heard renown, but never saw before; of whom I have received a second life; and second father this lady makes him to me.
I am hers: but, O, how oddly will it sound that I must ask my child forgiveness!
There, sir, stop: let us not burthen our remembrance with a heaviness that's gone.
I have inly wept, or should have spoke ere now. Look down, you gods, and on this couple drop a blessed crown!
For it is you that have chalked forth the way which brought us hither.
lines.annotation: 'Chalked forth': marked out in chalk, as a route or course.

lines.text: I say, Amen, Gonzalo!
Was Milan thrust from Milan, that his issue should become kings of Naples? O, rejoice beyond a common joy, and set it down with gold on lasting pillars:
lines.annotation: Gonzalo means: was Prospero driven out of Milan so that his daughter could end up queen of Naples? He frames the exile as a necessary step to a greater outcome.

lines.text: in one voyage did Claribel her husband find at Tunis; and Ferdinand, her brother, found a wife where he himself was lost; Prospero his dukedom in a poor isle; and all of us ourselves when no man was his own.
lines.annotation: Claribel is Alonso's daughter, married to the King of Tunis earlier in the voyage ‚Äî mentioned in Act II. Gonzalo is drawing all the threads together.

lines.text: Ariel enters with the Shipmaster and Boatswain.
O, look, sir, look, sir! Here is more of us: I prophesied, if a gallows were on land, this fellow could not drown.
lines.annotation: A reference to the Boatswain, whom Gonzalo cursed in Act I, saying he looked born to be hanged ‚Äî meaning he'd never drown.

lines.text: The best news is, that we have safely found our king and company; the next, our ship ‚Äî which, but three glasses since, we gave out split ‚Äî is tight and yare and bravely rigged as when we first put out to sea.
lines.annotation: 'Three glasses': three hours ‚Äî a ship's glass being a half-hour sandglass. 'Tight and yare': watertight and ready to sail.

lines.text: Was't well done?
lines.annotation: Aside to Prospero.

lines.text: Bravely, my diligence. Thou shalt be free.
lines.annotation: Aside to Ariel.

lines.text: These are not natural events; they strengthen from strange to stranger. Say, how came you hither?
If I did think, sir, I were well awake, I'd strive to tell you. We were dead of sleep, and ‚Äî how we know not ‚Äî all clapped under hatches;
where but even now with strange and several noises of roaring, shrieking, howling, jingling chains and more diversity of sounds, all horrible, we were awaked;

straightway, at liberty; where we, in all her trim, freshly beheld our royal, good and gallant ship, our master capering to see her: on a trice, so please you, even in a dream, were we divided from them and were brought moping hither.
lines.annotation: 'Moping': dazed, in a stupor.

lines.text: Was't so? Then say how went things on the shore?
Some oracle must rectify our knowledge.

Sir, my liege, do not infest your mind with beating on the strangeness of this business; at picked leisure which shall be shortly, single I'll resolve you, which to you shall seem probable, of every these happened accidents;
lines.annotation: 'Infest': trouble, disturb. 'Single': privately, one to one.

lines.text: till when, be cheerful, and think of each thing well.
Aside to Ariel.
Come hither, spirit: set Caliban and his companions free; untie the spell.
Ariel exits.
How fares my gracious sir? There are yet missing of your company some few odd lads that you remember not.
Ariel drives in Caliban, Stephano, and Trinculo, still in their stolen clothes.
Every man shift for all the rest, and let no man take care for himself; for all is but fortune.
lines.annotation: A garbled inversion of 'every man for himself' ‚Äî Stephano is still drunk.

lines.text: If these be true spies which I wear in my head, here's a goodly sight.
O Setebos, these be brave spirits indeed! How fine my master is! I am afraid he will chastise me.
lines.annotation: Setebos: a god of the Patagonian people, mentioned in travel accounts of the period. Shakespeare assigns this deity to Caliban's mother Sycorax.

lines.text: Ha, ha! What things are these, my lord Antonio? Will money buy 'em?
Very like; one of them is a plain fish, and, no doubt, marketable.
lines.annotation: Sebastian and Antonio immediately think in terms of commercial display ‚Äî Trinculo had the same instinct in Act II when he first saw Caliban.

lines.text: Mark but the badges of these men, my lords, then say if they be true. This mis-shapen knave, his mother was a witch, and one so strong that could control the moon, make flows and ebbs,
and deal in her command without her power: these three have robbed me; and this demi-devil ‚Äî for he's a bastard one ‚Äî had plotted with them to take my life.
lines.annotation: 'Badges': identifying marks on a servant's livery ‚Äî here the stolen clothing is evidence of the theft.

lines.text: Two of these fellows you must know and own; this thing of darkness I acknowledge mine.
lines.annotation: Prospero takes responsibility for Caliban ‚Äî 'this thing of darkness I acknowledge mine' is one of the most discussed lines in the play.

lines.text: I shall be pinched to death.
Is not this Stephano, my drunken butler?
He is drunk now: where had he wine?
And Trinculo is reeling ripe: where should they find this grand liquor that hath gilded 'em?
lines.annotation: 'Gilded': flushed red with drink.

lines.text: I have been in such a pickle since I saw you last that, I fear me, will never out of my bones: I shall not fear fly-blowing.
lines.annotation: 'Pickle': brine used for preserving food ‚Äî Trinculo is saying he's been so thoroughly soaked that he won't rot. 'Fly-blowing': contamination by flies laying eggs in meat.

lines.text: Why, how now, Stephano!
O, touch me not; I am not Stephano, but a cramp.
You'd be king o' the isle, sirrah?
I should have been a sore one then.
This is a strange thing as e'er I looked on.
lines.annotation: Alonso is looking at Caliban.

lines.text: He is as disproportioned in his manners as in his shape. Go, sirrah, to my cell; take with you your companions; as you look to have my pardon, trim it handsomely.
Ay, that I will; and I'll be wise hereafter and seek for grace. What a thrice-double ass was I, to take this drunkard for a god and worship this dull fool!
Go to; away!
Caliban, Stephano, and Trinculo exit.

Sir, I invite your highness and your train to my poor cell, where you shall take your rest for this one night; which, part of it, I'll waste with such discourse as, I not doubt, shall make it go quick away;
the story of my life and the particular accidents gone by since I came to this isle: and in the morn I'll bring you to your ship and so to Naples,
where I have hope to see the nuptial of these our dear-beloved solemnized; and thence retire me to my Milan, where every third thought shall be my grave.
I long to hear the story of your life, which must take the ear strangely.
I'll deliver all; and promise you calm seas, auspicious gales and sail so expeditious that shall catch your royal fleet far off.
Aside to Ariel.
My Ariel, chick, that is thy charge: then to the elements be free, and fare thou well!
Ariel exits for the last time.
Please you, draw near.
All exit.
End of Act V, Scene 1.
Epilogue ‚Äî Prospero alone on stage.
Now my charms are all o'erthrown, and what strength I have's mine own, which is most faint: now, 'tis true, I must be here confined by you, or sent to Naples.
lines.annotation: The Epilogue steps outside the play's fiction. Prospero addresses the theatre audience directly, asking them to release him by applauding ‚Äî a conventional ending for a masque.

lines.text: Let me not, since I have my dukedom got and pardoned the deceiver, dwell in this bare island by your spell; but release me from my bands with the help of your good hands.
Gentle breath of yours my sails must fill, or else my project fails, which was to please.
lines.annotation: 'Gentle breath': applause, or the audience's approving murmur.

lines.text: Now I want spirits to enforce, art to enchant, and my ending is despair, unless I be relieved by prayer,
lines.annotation: 'Want': lack.

lines.text: which pierces so that it assaults mercy itself and frees all faults.
As you from crimes would pardoned be, let your indulgence set me free.
lines.annotation: The Epilogue ends the play on the same theme of forgiveness it has been working through.

lines.text: End of The Tempest.
